{"uri": "8202089462", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "23:50:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T23:50:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T23:49:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/lebron-james-contract-lakers-free-agency/", "title": "LeBron James' Next Contract May Hinge on What the Lakers Do in Free Agency", "body": "Highlights LeBron James has opted out of his contract and is reportedly willing to take a pay cut to help improve Lakers roster. James is reportedly willing to take less money to bring in players like James Harden, Klay Thompson, and Jonas Valan\u010di\u016bnas. Time is limited for roster changes due to James' participation in the Summer Olympics.\n\nLeBron James and the Los Angeles Lakers have some work to do in the offseason.\n\nWhile James is undoubtedly delighted that the Lakers just drafted his son, Bronny James, in the second round of the 2024 NBA Draft, Los Angeles still has quite a few moves it will need to make if its hopes to be contending at the top of the Western Conference next season.\n\nOn Saturday, James opted out of the final year of his contract with the Lakers in order to sign a new deal. According to a report from ESPN's Dave McMenamin, James is open to taking a pay cut, but only if it means that it helps the Lakers land another superstar.\n\n\"He is prioritizing a roster improvement. He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.\" - Rich Paul\n\nJames Willing to Take Pay Cut to Land a Star Some notable names were identified as potential targets\n\nPer McMenamin, James is willing to take less than a max deal if it means the Lakers are able to use the midlevel exception to sign a difference-making player. James Harden, Klay Thompson, and big man Jonas Valan\u010di\u016bnas all were cited as players that could make the move worth it.\n\nIf the Lakers are unable to land a big fish in free agency, James will be looking for another max deal.\n\nMaking matters more pressing for the Lakers is the fact that all of these moves will have to be made on a condensed timeline. With James set to represent Team USA at the upcoming Summer Olympics in Paris, there are only a few weeks for Rob Pelinka and company to get their ducks in a row before the ball is rolling towards the start of the next NBA season.\n\nThat said, once the dominoes of NBA free agency start falling, things tend to move pretty fast. The Lakers will likely know where they stand with the marquee free agents that are available sooner rather than later.\n\nIt's No Surprise James Is Looking to Help the Lakers Reload The Western Conference is packed with talent, and James needs some help.\n\nJames' run with the Lakers has already produced one NBA championship, but if it's going to produce another, Los Angeles is going to have to make some moves.\n\nWhile James is still playing at an elite level, he will turn 40 during the next NBA season, and there's no telling how long he'll continue to play. Bronny getting drafted will likely keep James in Los Angeles for at least a few more years, but things could change at a moment's notice.\n\nAnthony Davis is still a superstar player and great match for James on the court, but the Lakers are undoubtedly short a star. Last year, Los Angeles had to battle through the play-in tournament to reach the full NBA postseason, and they were unceremoniously ousted in the first round by the Denver Nuggets in five games.\n\nLos Angeles Lakers Superstar Tandem -- Stats 2023-24 Season\n\nCategory\n\nLeBron James\n\nAnthony Timberwolves already elite and likely to be better in the coming season, there is certainly room on the Lakers' roster for another star.\n\nWhether or not they are able to land one remains to be LeBron has continued to play at an All-NBA level and will be treated as such.\n\nJames can now re-sign with the Lakers for a maximum of three years, $162 million. It would take him into his 24th and age 42 season. He can also add a no-trade clause, which is something he is said to be interested in.\n\nWhile the Lakers are willing to take care of LeBron James by offering him a full max contract, it appears that may not be necessary.\n\nRecent reports have indicated that James may be willing to take a bit of a pay cut if it can lead to roster upgrades for the Lakers.\n\nL.A. is not in the best spot with the cap as they are right at the second apron. his uniform would have \"James Jr.\" on the back.\n\nThe club has said they want to re-sign the elder James, a four-time NBA Most Valuable Player, and could swing a deal with him that would provide James signs shorter deals in free agency, a decision that gives him more flexibility in a constantly-changing NBA.\n\nThis year, LeBron will enter his 22nd season. He'll tie Vince Carter for the most seasons played in NBA history, a record James appears destined to shatter.\n\nAt 39, James is still playing at an All-NBA level. He averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds last season, helped the Lakers win the first-ever In-Season Tournament and led them to another playoff appearance.\n\nIf LeBron returns to the Lakers as expected, he'll be joined by his oldest son Bronny. draft status has no bearing on LeBron's choice in free agency, but it's hard to believe that he would pass on the chance to play on the same team as his son.\n\nWe'll see what he ultimately does, but {"uri": "8202017908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "21:57:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T21:57:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T21:57:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/lebron-james-opts-out-of-lakers-contract-but-expected-to-sign-new-deal-with-la-162729038.html", "title": "LeBron James opts out of Lakers contract but expected to sign new deal with LA", "body": "James is eligible to sign a three-year, $162 million maximum contract to return to the Lakers in free agency\n\nLeBron James has opted out of his contract with the Los Angeles Lakers for next season, his agent, Rich Paul, told ESPN's Dave McMenamin, but he's not expected to a free agent for long.\n\nAccording to Paul, James is willing to work with the Lakers on a new deal that would come in below the maximum three-year, $162 million deal he is eligible for in order to open up the full $12.9 million mid-level exception to allow general manager Rob Pelinka to sign an \"impact player.\"\n\nWhat type of \"impact player?\" According to ESPN, that could be James Harden, Klay Thompson, who's expected to hit free agency, or a big man who can play alongside Anthony Davis.\n\nJames had until 5 p.m. ET to inform the Lakers of his decision.\n\nThe last time he was a free agent, James joined the Lakers in 2018, signing a four-year, $154 million deal to go west. He signed a two-year, $97.1 million extension with Los Angeles in 2022, which included a player option for this upcoming season.\n\nJames is eligible to sign a three-year, $162 million maximum contract to return to the Lakers in free agency. He is also eligible to sign with any other team in the NBA for a maximum of $157.5 million over the next three seasons. (The NBA limits contracts for players over 38 years old to three-year maximums.)\n\nThe 39-year-old is the oldest active player in the NBA but shows no signs of slowing down. James averaged 25.7 points (on 54/41/75 shooting splits), 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds per game this past season, making the All-NBA third team. He led the Lakers to a play-in tournament berth and the No. 7 seed in the Western Conference. They lost to the Denver Nuggets in the opening round of the playoffs.\n\nAlthough his free agency decisions are unclear, James said that he wanted to retire as a Laker during the 2024 All-Star Weekend in February.\n\n\"I am a Laker, and I've been very happy being a Laker the last six years, and hopefully it stays that way,\" James said, just before making a record-breaking 20th All-Star appearance.\n\nAnother consideration was James' son, Bronny, who was drafted by the Lakers with the No. 55 overall pick on Thursday. James has said repeatedly that he hopes to play his final NBA season with Bronny, but recently said that he won't necessarily leave the Lakers to join his son if he gets drafted by another team, and his agent Rich Paul clarified that the two are not a packaged deal.\n\nAt this point, the Philadelphia 76ers are the only championship contender with maximum salary cap space. James could also orchestrate a sign-and-trade deal elsewhere or sign anywhere for as little as the veteran minimum, though Paul all but ruled out the latter to ESPN's Jonathan Givony.\n\n\"LeBron is also not going to Phoenix for a minimum deal,\" said Paul. \"We can squash that now.\"\n\nAt the very least, James will take a pay cut for the 2024-25 season. His maximum starting salary of $50 million is almost $1.5 million less than was his option to play for the Lakers. By becoming a free agent, he can now negotiate a no-trade clause with the Lakers in addition to securing a longer-term contract. This remains the most likely scenario. They are the NBA's first father-son duo. LeBron has talked about wanting to close out his career playing with his son. Now, it's a reality.\n\n\"I need to be on the floor with my boy, I got to be on the floor with Bronny,\" James told ESPN in 2023. \"Either in the same uniform or a matchup against him. ... I saw him work out a couple times besides the [Klutch Sports] pro day and working with a big -- his reads, reading the defense, making the right passes -- that was really impressive to me. He has LeBron James DNA and I am gonna take the bet on that...and then you watch him play, he is a good basketball player,\" Green said on his podcast. \"I'm goin to take that bet because you got him at 55, so he even becomes a rotation player, you did great and I think he could possibly become a rotational player in the next two years.\"\n\nThe father-son duo playing together isn't completely locked in just yet. LeBron James is weighing a $51.4 million player option. That would likely keep James in LA for the rest of his career. {"uri": "2024-06-405986318", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "18:06:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T18:06:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T16:38:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://fadeawayworld.net/lebron-james-contract-become-free-agent-lakers-return-likely", "title": "LeBron James Opts Out Of Contract To Become Free Agent; Lakers Return Likely", "body": "LeBron James, the four-time NBA champion and perennial All-Star, has decided to opt out of the final year of his contract worth $51.4 million with the Los Angeles Lakers, according to reports.\n\nWhile this move allows James to explore free agency, the expectation is that he will sign a new deal with the Lakers. This decision follows a series of strategic moves by the Lakers, including the selection of his son, Bronny James, with the No. 55 overall pick in the NBA Draft, and the hiring of his podcast co-host, JJ Redick, as their head coach.\n\nJames is eligible for a new three-year deal worth a projected $160 million, which would include a no-trade clause, an element he could not have included in a mere contract extension.\n\nBy opting out and signing a new contract, James secures both financial and strategic advantages, ensuring that any future trade would require his approval. This move provides James with greater control over his career trajectory as he continues to play at an elite level.\n\nSince joining the Lakers in 2018, James has been a cornerstone of the franchise, leading them to an NBA championship in 2020. If he signs the anticipated three-year deal, his tenure with the Lakers could extend to nine seasons, surpassing his initial seven-year stint with the Cleveland Cavaliers.\n\nDespite turning 40 next season, James continues to defy age, maintaining impressive averages of 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds, and 8.3 assists per game last season.\n\nThe Lakers, under General Manager Rob Pelinka, have emphasized the importance of balancing immediate success with long-term development. This approach is evident in their recent draft picks and the potential for further roster upgrades. The Lakers need to address their weaknesses and build a team capable of contending for a championship, particularly given their early playoff exit last season at the hands of the Denver Nuggets.\n\nJames' decision to opt-out is a calculated move, allowing him to leverage his position and ensure that the Lakers remain committed to building a competitive roster around him. The Lakers' management is likely prepared for this development and is expected to make the necessary adjustments to retain their star player and enhance the team's championship prospects.\n\nWhile LeBron James' opt-out may initially appear to introduce uncertainty, all signs point to his continued presence with the Lakers. This strategic move aims to secure his legacy and position the team for future success, reinforcing the mutual commitment between James and the Lakers organization.\n\nThe Lakers Have To Give LeBron James A Chance By Building A Strong Roster\n\nThe Lakers must seize the opportunity to give LeBron James a legitimate chance to win another title before he concludes his illustrious career. With reports suggesting that LeBron will likely sign a three-year extension, this would extend his career to an unprecedented 24 seasons in the NBA.\n\nLeBron has achieved an extraordinary amount in his career, but his drive for another championship remains undiminished. Remarkably, even in his 21st year, LeBron is still considered a top 10 talent in the league, a feat unparalleled in NBA history. The four-time champion, four-time MVP, and 20-time All-Star is now playing alongside his son, Bronny James, fulfilling a long-held dream. The possibility of winning a championship with his son only heightens his motivation.\n\nTo honor LeBron's legacy and maximize this unique opportunity, the Lakers need to build a robust roster around him and Anthony Davis. This means making strategic moves in the offseason to bring in key players who can complement their play styles and elevate the team's overall performance.\n\nThe Lakers' management must be willing to make the necessary financial commitments, even if it means paying the luxury tax due to surpassing the second apron. They are already over the first luxury tax threshold, indicating a willingness to invest in a championship-caliber team.\n\nThe Lakers need to be aggressive in free agency and potential trades to acquire seasoned veterans and young talents who can contribute immediately. Role players who can provide consistent scoring, defensive prowess, and depth are crucial to the team's success.\n\nLeBron's window for winning another championship is narrowing, but his performance and leadership continue to inspire. The Lakers must capitalize on this by assembling a team that can compete at the highest level.\n\nWith LeBron's experience and determination, combined with a well-rounded and capable supporting cast, the Lakers can make a serious run at another title. It is not just about honoring LeBron's legacy; it is about giving a legendary player the tools he needs to achieve greatness once more. The time for the Lakers to act is now, ensuring that LeBron has every chance to add another championship to his storied career.\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "8201789205", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "17:06:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T17:06:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T17:06:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/nba/news/lebron-james-opt-out-lakers-star-free-agency-bronny-james/52dbf22550e93ff0d53cdf21", "title": "Why did LeBron James opt out? Lakers star headed for free agency despite Bronny James selection", "body": "Bronny James is a Laker. By Sunday night, LeBron James won't be.\n\nJames intends to opt out of his contract with the Lakers, declining a $51.4 million player option to hit free agency along with the rest of the class at 6 p.m. ET on Sunday.\n\nJames is entering his 22nd NBA season, but he hasn't shown many signs of slowing down. While retirement talk has bubbled up a bit over the last two years, there was little doubt James would keep playing with his son in the NBA.\n\nCould James really pass on the opportunity to be teammates with Bronny? Here's what you need to know about the reasoning behind the NBA great's decision to become a free agent.\n\nMORE: Tracking the latest LeBron James free agency rumors\n\nJames is expected to sign a new deal with the Lakers, according to The Athletic's Shams Charania. While that might not stop certain teams from trying to lure him away, the report comes as no surprise after the selection of his son and the hiring of his close friend, JJ Redick, as head coach.\n\nSo, why would James opt out at all? There are a few benefits.\n\nRather than play out the final season of his contract for $51.4 million, James is eligible to sign a three-year, $162 million deal to stay in Los Angeles. That's not only an increase of $2.6 million for the 2024-25 season, but it affords the four-time NBA champion more long-term security through his 24th season.\n\nA new deal in free agency would also allow James to secure a no-trade clause, if he wishes. A no-trade clause would not have been possible with a simple extension keeping him off the open market. It's highly unlikely the Lakers would trade James without his permission to begin with, but most players value that kind of security.\n\nJames' foray into free agency could also put pressure on the Lakers to upgrade their roster. If he isn't happy with the way the team is built, James could entertain interest from other teams and force GM Rob Pelinka's hand to trade for an impact player.\n\nIt's not uncommon for James to enter free agency without any expectation of leaving his current team. He opted-out of his deal with the Cavaliers in both 2015 and 2016 despite no realistic chance of exiting Cleveland. James even remained a free agent for six weeks in 2016, not re-signing with the Cavaliers until mid-August, without any speculation that he might sign elsewhere.\n\nLakers fans shouldn't panic despite the uncertainty of James entering free agency. After recent moves by the franchise, it would be a giant surprise to see the all-time points leader leave Los Angeles.\n\nMORE: NBA players react to Lakers' Bronny James selection\n\nJames is eligible to sign a three-year, $162 million contract to return to the Lakers. That would pay him $54 million per year through the 2026-27 season, which would be his 24th in the NBA.\n\nA long-term contract doesn't by any means guarantee that James isn't retiring until 2027, but it does provide long-term security and potentially a no-trade clause that puts the star in control of his future. The contract would also boost his salary from the $51.4 million mark that he would've made if he had exercised his player option.\n\nJames is set to cruise past $500 million in career earnings next season, simply from NBA contracts alone.\n\nJames is 39 years old. He's set to turn 40 on Dec. 30.\n\nIt goes without saying James has been otherworldly in recent years considering his age and the ridiculous amount of wear-and-tear on his body. James averaged 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds and 8.3 assists per game in his age-39 season, posting his highest field goal percentage in seven years.\n\nWhile 40-year-olds don't typically make $54 million per year, let alone actively play in the NBA at all, the Lakers aren't expected to have any qualms about giving James the contract he's looking for.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": Bronny was drafted by the Lakers in the second round of the 2024 NBA Draft.\n\nThe two are now the first father and son to ever play together in the NBA. There is a lot of change in the air for the Lakers this coming year, as JJ Redick is also the new head coach for the team. Redick is a former league player who has never held a head coaching position in the NBA.\n\nThe Lakers and their fans hope that the James duo, as well as Redick, can bring a NBA Championship back to the city. Los Angeles bowed to the Denver Nuggets in this year's Western Conference playoffs. The Lakers lost to Denver in five games. Bronny did not have a strong season in college basketball, playing for USC in 2023-24. The Trojans missed the NCAA tournament, and finished with a losing season. Bronny averaged under 5 points a game, playing in a limited role due to a heart injury. The team did find some rhythm as the season was about to end, but Bronny didn't have a single game scoring in double figures after a January 17 contest against Arizona.\n\nCritics say Bronny is only with the Lakers because of his dad, LeBron. It could be considered fair criticism, but Bronny will surely get his chance to prove his doubters wrong. The young star reportedly had a strong showing in the NBA Combine, and several other franchises were rumored to want Bronny in the draft. In the end, he is headed to Los Angeles, where he will team with his dad and Anthony Davis to try and win another title.\n\nThe Lakers were rumored this offseason to have to fight to keep LeBron. It seems the team won't have that problem now. The 20-plus year veteran averaged nearly 26 points this past season. He also grabbed 7 rebounds a contest. Despite his age, LeBron still has plenty of gas in the tank. {"uri": "8201891838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "19:05:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T19:05:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T19:04:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/lebron-james-willing-take-pay-cut-free-agency/", "title": "LeBron James Willing To Take Pay Cut To Improve Lakers' Title Hopes", "body": "Highlights LeBron James may take a pay cut to help Lakers sign better free agents. LeBron's potential pay cut would make the Lakers eligible for the full midlevel exception. The Lakers could target players like Derrick Jones Jr. and Jonas Valanciunas.\n\nLos Angeles Lakers star LeBron James will officially become an unrestricted free agent after he reportedly intends to opt out of his $51.4 million player option. Nonetheless, James isn't expected to leave Los Angeles and should re-sign with the Lakers on a new contract.\n\nThough James is eligible to sign a maximum deal worth $162 million over the next three years, the four-time NBA champion could take a paycut to enhance the Lakers' chances of competing for a championship. Senior NBA Insider Chris Haynes of TNT and Bleacher Report noted that James is considering taking less money so that the Lakers can open up the full midlevel exception in free agency.\n\nWhat LeBron James Taking Pay Cut Means for Lakers L.A. can target more free agents\n\nThis isn't the first time that James has taken a pay cut in order to enhance his team's chances of winning a championship. He did so back in 2010 when he, along with Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh, all took less money to join forces with the Miami Heat. With the Lakers still needing more pieces to improve, James may be willing to do the same now that he is in the twilight of his career.\n\nIf James inks a max deal, this would take the Lakers over the first apron, which makes them eligible for the taxpayers' midlevel exception. This means they can only sign a player for a two-year deal worth up to $10.6 million.\n\nShould James take a pay cut, Los Angeles will be eligible for the full midlevel exception. This will allow the Lakers to offer a contract with a starting salary of $12.9 million and up to $55.3 million over the next four years.\n\nBut how much would James need to give up to make this happen? ESPN's Brian Windhorst hinted on his podcast about this possibility a couple of days ago and projected that the Lakers star could give up around $10 to $12 million and sign a contract in the $38 to $39 million range annually.\n\nLakers' Potential Targets in Free Agency James is still seeking to win his fifth NBA championship\n\nIf James is indeed willing to take a salary hit, this obviously increases the Lakers' pool of potential targets in free agency. Not only is there more money in what they can offer, they could also extend a longer deal.\n\nGrant Asfeth floated the idea of the Lakers going after free agent wing Derrick Jones Jr., who recently moved to Klutch Sports Group, the same agency that James and his co-star Anthony Davis are with.\n\nJones had a terrific campaign with the Dallas Mavericks and was a key starter in their run to the NBA Finals. Dallas, however, has been able to clear up the cap room to re-sign Jones in free agency via the same full MLE the Lakers are trying to vie for.\n\nAnother potential target for Los Angeles is Jonas Valanciunas, who has been linked to the Lakers at some point this summer. Valanciunas would be a great addition to shore up the front line for Los Angeles and allow Davis to play his preferred power forward position.\n\nNonetheless, nothing is set in stone just yet. The Lakers will likely still need to convince James to make this move and a lot of that will be dependent on who they can realistically bring in to increase their chances of giving The King his fifth NBA championship.\n\nRelated Lakers' LeBron James Will Become Unrestricted Free Agent\n\nJames is expected to sign a new deal with the Lakers in free agency.", "source": {"uri": "givemesport.com", {"uri": "8201767390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "16:42:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T16:42:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T16:42:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/lebron-james-reportedly-intends-to-opt-out-of-lakers-contract-but-expected-to-sign-new-deal-with-la-162729480.html", "title": "LeBron James reportedly intends to opt out of Lakers contract but expected to sign new deal with LA", "body": "James is eligible to sign a three-year, $162 million maximum contract to return to the Lakers in free agency\n\nLeBron James is reportedly planing to opt out of his player option for next season, but won't be a free agent for long.\n\nIn advance of the Saturday deadline on his decision, the 39-year-old superstar declined his $51.4 million option to play for the Los Angeles Lakers next season, but is expected to return to the Lakers with a new deal in free agency, according to multiple reports.\n\nThe last time he was a free agent, James joined the Lakers in 2018, signing a four-year, $154 million deal to go west. He signed a two-year, $97.1 million extension with Los Angeles in 2022, which included a player option for this upcoming season.\n\nJames is eligible to sign a three-year, $162 million maximum contract to return to the Lakers in free agency. He is also eligible to sign with any other team in the NBA for a maximum of $157.5 million over the next three seasons. (The NBA limits contracts for players over 38 years old to three-year maximums.)\n\nThe 39-year-old is the oldest active player in the NBA but shows no signs of slowing down. James averaged 25.7 points (on 54/41/75 shooting splits), 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds per game this past season, making the All-NBA third team. He led the Lakers to a play-in tournament berth and the No. 7 seed in the Western Conference. They lost to the Denver Nuggets in the opening round of the playoffs.\n\nAlthough his free agency decisions are unclear, James said that he wanted to retire as a Laker during the 2024 All-Star Weekend in February.\n\n\"I am a Laker, and I've been very happy being a Laker the last six years, and hopefully it stays that way,\" James said, just before making a record-breaking 20th All-Star appearance.\n\nAnother consideration was James's son, Bronny, who was drafted by the Lakers with the No. 55 overall pick on Thursday. James has said repeatedly that he hopes to play his final NBA season with Bronny, but recently said that he won't necessarily leave the Lakers to join his son if he gets drafted by another team, and his agent Rich Paul clarified that the two are not a packaged deal.\n\nAt this point, the Philadelphia 76ers are the only championship contender with maximum salary cap space. James could also orchestrate a sign-and-trade deal elsewhere or sign anywhere for as little as the veteran minimum, though Paul all but ruled out the latter to ESPN's Jonathan Givony.\n\n\"LeBron is also not going to Phoenix for a minimum deal,\" said Paul. \"We can squash that now.\"\n\nAt the very least, James will take a pay cut for the 2024-25 season. His maximum starting salary of $50 million is almost $1.5 million less than was his option to play for the Lakers. By becoming a free agent, he can now negotiate a no-trade clause with the Lakers in addition to securing a longer-term contract. This remains the most likely scenario. {"uri": "8201746556", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "16:22:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T16:22:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T16:22:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/lebron-james-to-opt-out-of-lakers-contract-but-expected-to-stay-on-new-deal-per-report/", "title": "LeBron James to opt out of Lakers contract, but expected to stay on new deal, per report - CBSSports.com", "body": "Getty Images\n\nLeBron James has decided to opt out of the final year of his contract with the Los Angeles Lakers, but the expectation is that he will sign a new deal with the team, according to The Athletic's Shams Charania. So far this offseason, the Lakers have selected his son, Bronny James, with the No. 55 overall pick in the NBA Draft, and they have also hired his Mind the Game podcast co-host, JJ Redick, as their head coach.\n\nJames is eligible for a three-year deal worth a projected $162 million to return to Los Angeles as a free agent. Because he has at least eight total years of NBA experience and has spent at least four years with the Lakers, he is also eligible for a no-trade clause in this deal.\n\nJames could have potentially signed an extension with the Lakers for a slightly higher price. The total amount on such an extension would have been roughly $164.3 million over three years. The reason such an extension would have paid James more is that his player option amount, which was based on an 8% raise built into his last contract, was higher than his max on the open market, which would have been a 5% raise on his previous salary. However, had James extended, he would not have been eligible for a no-trade clause, as those can only be added to new deals rather than existing ones.\n\nJames has spent the past six seasons with the Lakers. If he signs that three-year max deal with the Lakers and doesn't move before it ends, his total Lakers tenure will have lasted nine seasons. That would top his first seven-year tenure with the the Cleveland Cavaliers for the longest stretch with a single team in his career. In total, though, he would need to play 11 seasons with the Lakers to match his overall time with the Cavaliers, as he went on to play four more years in Cleveland later on.\n\nThe Lakers won 47 games a year ago and were knocked out of the playoffs in the first round by the Denver Nuggets. Reports have indicated that James still hopes to compete for championships, but the Lakers, thus far, have not made significant moves to improve. They landed Dalton Knecht at No. 17 overall in the draft, but they have not made a substantial veteran addition yet this offseason. The Lakers have preached patience and player development so far this offseason, but as James will turn 40 next season, they will have to find a balance between the present and future.\n\nGeneral manager Rob Pelinka has in the past said that the Lakers need to be \"caretakers\" of James' legacy as one of the greatest players in NBA history. That has meant investing in immediate winning, and after losing in the first round, upgrades will be needed to put this team in a position to genuinely compete this season. Only time will tell if the Lakers are able to make those moves, but if James does indeed stay on a new deal, he will be entrusting the team to do so.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": James is not opting into what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead will seek a new deal with the Lakers, a person with knowledge of the decision said Saturday, June 29, 2024.\n\nLeBron James is not opting into what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead will seek a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, a person with knowledge of the decision said Saturday.\n\nThe terms of the new deal could be finalized quickly, said the person, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because neither James nor the Lakers revealed the decision publicly. ESPN, The Athletic and the Los Angeles Times all reported the decision earlier Saturday.\n\nThe move is among those coming just ahead of the NBA's free agency period, which formally opens at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, though at least $1.2 billion in contracts already have been agreed upon because of new rules that allowed teams to speak with their own players about new deals -- in many situations -- starting on the day after the NBA Finals.\n\nAmong those already having agreed to deals that cannot be finalized until the new league year opens on July 6: Toronto teammates Scottie Barnes and Immanuel Quickley, Miami's Bam Adebayo, Indiana's Pascal Siakam, and New York's OG Anunoby.\n\nIt was expected that LeBron James would technically be a free agent. It's also been expected that he would stay with the Lakers.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nThe Lakers selected Bronny James -- LeBron James' oldest son -- on Thursday in the second round of the draft, putting them in position to have the first on-court father-son duo in NBA history. And with a new deal, it's even possible that LeBron James could sign for a lower number than he could have commanded to give the Lakers additional financial flexibility for other moves.\n\nLeBron James is a four-time champion and is about $20 million shy of becoming the first player in league history to top $500 million in on-court earnings. Add in his many off-court ventures and investments, and his net worth has been presumed to be more than $1 billion for some time now.\n\nHe'll turn 40 in December and will tie Vince Carter this season in terms of most seasons played in NBA history; the 2024-25 campaign will be James' 22nd in the league. {"uri": "8201748045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "16:24:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T16:24:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T16:23:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://s22928.pcdn.co/lakers-rumors-lebron-james-opts-out-but-expected-to-re-sign/", "title": "Lakers Rumors: LeBron James Opts Out But Expected To Re-Sign", "body": "For the second straight year, Los Angeles Lakers star LeBron James played it coy about his future at the conclusion of the season.\n\nLast year after losing to the Denver Nuggets in the Western Conference Finals, James teased the possibility of retirement after 20 NBA seasons. He of course came back and had another exceptional year for the Lakers though, showing that he is still capable of playing at an All-NBA level even at his age.\n\nThis offseason is different though as while retirement never seemed like a possibility for LeBron, leaving the Lakers is. He came into the summer with a player option for just over $51 million, but the expectation all along was that he would decline it to sign a bigger contract with L.A. or maybe even to test free agency and see what else is out there.\n\nWhile the expectation isn't necessarily that James will leave, especially now that the team has drafted his son Bronny James, he has indeed declined his player option to become a free agent, per Shams Charania of The Athletic:\n\nReports indicated early in the offseason that the Lakers are willing to offer James any contract he is interested in, including the maximum three-year, $164 million extension. As he gets set to enter his 22nd season while turning 40 later this year, the expectation is that James will play at least two more years.\n\nAt this stage of his career, James is only interested in competing for championships so the Lakers obviously have some work to do to get to that level. It will be fascinating to see if LeBron inks an extension before Rob Pelinka and the front office make their offseason moves, or if he will wait to see what the roster looks like before deciding on his future with the organization.\n\nThey did end up hiring his friend and podcast co-host JJ Redick to be their head coach though, in addition to drafting Bronny, so all indications remain that James will stay in L.A.\n\nOne thing that will be important moving forward is LeBron James' vision being aligned with the Lakers', and that starts up top with owner and governor Jeanie Buss.\n\nAccording to {"uri": "2024-06-405981033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "17:57:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T17:57:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T17:25:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.aol.com/lebron-james-becomes-free-agent-172551679.html", "title": "LeBron James to free agency after declining Los Angeles Lakers contract option", "body": "LeBron James to free agency after declining Los Angeles Lakers contract option\n\nJeff Zillgitt, USA TODAY\n\nJune 29, 2024 at 7:25 PM\n\nLeBron James has declined the player option on the final season of his contract with the Los Angeles Lakers, making him a free agent when free agency begins Sunday, a person familiar with the decision told USA TODAY Sports.\n\nThe person requested anonymity because he was not authorized to speak publicly about James' plans.\n\nDespite the opt-out, it's expected that James will re-sign with the Lakers - especially after they selected his son Bronny with the 55th overall pick in the second round of the NBA draft Thursday.\n\nJames, who turns 40 on Dec. 30, could've exercised his player option and played the final year of his contract with the Lakers in 2024-25 for $51.4 million.\n\nIf James wants to stay a Laker - and he said as much at All-Star Weekend in February when asked by USA TODAY Sports - and have control over his future, opting out and re-signing with the Lakers on a three-year, $162 million deal is the best option.\n\nHe can include a no-trade clause in a new deal, which would silence any talk about the Lakers sending James to another team.\n\n\"I am a Laker, and I am happy and been very happy being a Laker the last six years, and hopefully it stays that way,\" he told USA TODAY Sports in February. \"But I don't have the answer to how long it is or which uniform I'll be in. Hopefully it is with the Lakers. It's a great organization and so many greats. But we'll see. I don't know how it's going to end (NBA playing career), but it's coming. It's coming, for sure.\"\n\nIf James wants to play elsewhere, he can get a three-year contract worth $157.5 million. Now, there aren't many teams with the kind of cap space available to sign James at the salary he wants. His agent Rich Paul, the CEO of Klutch Sports, shot down the idea of James signing a minimum contract to play for a contender. If James wants to remain on a competitive team, that narrows his options outside of the Lakers.\n\nHe averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists, 7.3 rebounds and 1.3 steals and shot 54% from the field and a career-high 41% on 3-pointers in 71 games in 2023-24 as he made the All-Star team for the 20th consecutive season and earned his 20th All-NBA selection.\n\nThe Lakers were eliminated from the playoffs by the Denver Nuggets for the second consecutive season - the Western Conference finals last season and first round this season.\n\nJames performed well in the playoffs, scoring at least 26 points in the five games, including 30 in Game 4 and 30 points, 11 assists, nine rebounds and four steals in Game 5, and shooting better than 50% from the field. But the gap between the two teams was exposed by Denver's second-half execution and the Lakers' slim margin of error.\n\nFollow NBA reporter Jeff Zillgitt on social media @JeffZillgitt\n\nThis article His initial contract with the Lakers was a four-year deal worth $154 million. James then signed a two-year extension in 2022 for $97.1 million with a player option for the 2024-25 season.\n\nMultiple reports indicate James will wear the purple and gold again next season and play with his oldest son Bronny James, who was taken with the 55th pick in the NBA Draft, and be coached by JJ Redick, who became the head coach of the Lakers earlier this month. James has until 5 p.m. ET on Saturday to tell the Lakers his decision, according to ESPN.\n\nJames, 39, is eligible for up to a three-year deal because the NBA limits players older than 38 to signing contracts for a maximum of three years. The Lakers can offer him $162 million over three years to return or another team can offer up to $157.5 million for the same duration and attempt to lure him away from Los Angeles. He said he wanted to retire as a Laker during last year's All-Star Weekend.\n\nJames has enjoyed numerous successes with the franchise, including winning an NBA title in 2020 and winning the inaugural NBA In-Season Tournament Championship in December 2023. {"uri": "8202176676", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:17:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:17:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:17:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://triblive.com/sports/lebron-james-intends-to-sign-with-lakers-ap-source-says/", "title": "LeBron James intends to sign with Lakers, AP source says", "body": "Lakers star LeBron James is not opting into what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead will seek a new deal with the Lakers.\n\nLeBron James is going to move toward a new contract with the Los Angeles Lakers. Paul George and Klay Thompson may simply be on the move to new teams.\n\nAnd the NBA's free agency period, which officially starts Sunday, suddenly has some intrigue.\n\nJames did not exercise his option to accept what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead is seeking a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, a person with knowledge of the decision said Saturday.\n\nThe terms of the new deal could be finalized quickly, said the person, who spoke to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity because neither James nor the Lakers revealed the decision publicly. ESPN, The Athletic and the Los Angeles Times all reported the decision earlier Saturday.\n\nMeanwhile, George made a similar decision, the nine-time All-Star choosing to not opt-in for what would have been a $48.8 million contract this coming season with the Los Angeles Clippers -- a team that he's spent the past five years with, averaging 23 points per game. He'll become a free agent and is planning to talk to the Clippers about a new deal and also intends to hear pitches from Orlando and Philadelphia, plus potentially others, a person briefed on George's plans told AP on Saturday night.\n\nSaturday's moves came just ahead of the NBA's free agency period, which formally opens at 6 p.m. on Sunday, though at least $1.2 billion in contracts already have been agreed upon because of new rules that allowed teams to speak with their own players about new deals -- in many situations -- starting on the day after the NBA Finals.\n\nAmong those already having agreed to deals that cannot be finalized until the new league year opens July 6: Toronto teammates Scottie Barnes and Immanuel Quickley, Miami's Bam Adebayo, Indiana's Pascal Siakam and New York's OG Anunoby.\n\nIt was expected James technically would be a free agent. It's also been expected he would stay with the Lakers.\n\nThe Lakers selected Bronny James, LeBron James' oldest son, Thursday in the second round of the draft, putting them in position to have the first on-court father-son duo in NBA history. And with a new deal, it's even possible LeBron James could sign for a lower number than he could have commanded to give the Lakers additional financial flexibility for other moves.\n\n\"He is prioritizing a roster improvement,\" James' agent, Klutch Sports CEO Rich Paul, told ESPN on Saturday. \"He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.\"\n\nLeBron James is a four-time champion and is about $20 million shy of becoming the first player in league history to top $500 million in on-court earnings. Add in his many off-court ventures and investments, and his net worth has been presumed to be more than $1 billion for some time now.\n\nHe'll turn 40 in December and will tie Vince Carter this season in terms of most seasons played in NBA history; the 2024-25 campaign will be James' 22nd in the league. He averaged 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds and 8.3 assists last season -- as the oldest active player in the league.\n\nAnd if he's going to leave money on the table, he's going to want a player who can help the Lakers contend for a title again. Among the Lakers' potential targets: Golden State's Thompson, a free agent who could be on the move for the first time in his career.\n\nThompson, a starter on all four of the Warriors' championship teams of this era and half of the famed \"Splash Brothers\" duo alongside 3-point king Stephen Curry, has spent all 13 of his NBA years with Golden State. And his status -- will he go back to the Warriors or not? -- is one of the biggest questions that'll be answered in the coming days. It may not be financially possible for Golden State to retain Thompson.\n\n\"We want him back. We've said that all along,\" Warriors general manager Mike Dunleavy said June 24. \"Hopefully he'll come back. But as far as the specifics and discussions and those types of things, I think it's important to keep in-house and that stuff. {"uri": "2024-06-405451436", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "04:35:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T04:35:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T04:14:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/lakers-new-lebron-james-shows-love-for-ex-lakers-star-over-bronny-james-approval", "title": "LeBron James shows love for ex-Lakers star over Bronny James approval", "body": "LeBron James was hyped about Nick Van Exel's Bronny James reaction.\n\nThe Los Angeles Lakers made one of the most polarizing moves of the 2024 NBA Draft on Thursday night. The Lakers selected former USC basketball guard Bronny James with their 55th pick. James' impeding professional debut has countless fans and athletes excited. One such athlete is former Lakers guard Nick Van Exel. LeBron James showed love for Van Excel after his Bronny James' draft praise.\n\nThis, of course, prompted a gracious response from LeBron James:\n\n\"That's so TOUGH!! Nick the Quick was cold!\" James responded.\n\nNick Van Exel spent 13 years in the NBA, with his first five seasons coming with the Lakers. Van Excel earned two key honors with Los Angeles. He made the 1993-94 All-Rookie Team and earned his first and lone All-Star appearance with the Lakers in 1997-98. The 6'1'' guard ended his NBA tenure with averages of 14.4 points and 6.6 assists.\n\nLeBron James was ecstatic to see Nick Van Excel support his son Bronny. But nobody was more excited than LeBron James himself. He wrote a touching message the day before the Lakers drafted Bronny to him and his brother Bryce.\n\n\"Not a feeling better in the f*** world than me being around raising my boys to MEN! Pops over here getting emotional as hell just thinking about y'all journey so far! Thank you both for allowing me to be your DAD and be a part of your compass through life's trials and tribulations! James wrote on Instagram alongside a series of endearing emojis.\n\nIt will be interesting to see how Bronny and Byrce James continue their impressive endeavors.\n\nBronny James turns a new chapter with the Lakers\n\nLos Angeles is hoping to bounce back from their 2024 first-round playoff exit. Bronny James may not immediately contribute to the team's ascent, but with time, he looks to make a big impact.\n\nJames averaged just 4.9 points and 0.8 steals during his freshman season with USC. His numbers were a contract to his high school senior production. James averaged 13.8 points and 1.8 steals during his final year at Sierra Canyon. However, his stats do not tell the full story.\n\nIn July of 2023, James suffered a cardiac arrest during a USC basketball practice. Thankfully, he fully recovered and returned to the court, but his rhythm was understandably not the same. Despite James' down freshman season, he impressed NBA Combine scouts with his vertical leap and pro lane agility performances. In addition, he bolstered the perception of his offensive abilities by scoring 13 points in his second scrimmage and performing well in shooting drills.\n\nLos Angeles believes Bronny James will have a bright NBA future. In the meantime, LeBron James will hold things down. James is coming off an impressive 2023-24 season. Through 71 games, the star forward averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists, 7.3 rebounds, 1.3 blocks, and 1.1 steals. In addition, he shot a career-high 41.0 percent on three-pointers. James and the rest of Los Angeles want to continue his all-around production to help the Lakers to an improved showing in 2024-25.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": James was due to make $51.4 million if he exercised his player option for the 2024-25 season.\n\nESPN reports the Lakers are \"committed to keeping James with the franchise\" and are willing to offer him a maximum, three-year, $162 million deal. While that is the max deal James is eligible for, the two sides could come to another agreement once they begin negotiating.\n\nJames just finished his sixth season with the Lakers and has maintained an incredible level of play as he has aged. He was named third team All-NBA during the 2023-24 campaign while averaging 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds and 8.3 assists in 35.2 minutes per game. He also shot a career-best 41% from three-point range and made 54% of his shots from the field.\n\nOn Friday, the Lakers deepened James's connection to the franchise by selecting his son Bronny with the 55th pick in the 2024 NBA Draft.\n\nLos Angeles is fully built around James at this point, so it's not shocking the two sides would like to continue their partnership. The Lakers hired his podcast co-host JJ Redick as their new head coach a few days before selecting Bronny in the draft.\n\nThe all-time great appears ready to end his career with the Lakers. The partnership has been successful, as James led the franchise to an NBA title in '20. But during his time in LA, the team has missed the playoffs twice, been eliminated in the first round twice and was swept in the conference finals in '23. Those results likely aren't up to James's standards.\n\nJames appears set to be back with the Lakers. We'll see if the franchise can make the most of his career's remaining years.\n\nThis article was originally published on www.si.com as LeBron James Plans to Opt Out, Re-Sign With Lakers, per They fired Darvin Ham, who didn't exactly get strong votes of confidence from his stars, and hired JJ Redick, who rather famously hosted a podcast with James in the second half of the season.\n\nIn the Draft, after landing Dalton Knecht in the first round, they used the 55th pick to take Bronny James and give LeBron the chance to fulfill his dream of playing in NBA games with his son. Saturday was the deadline for players and teams to pick up or decline contract options, and as most expected, LeBron declined his $51.4 million option to enter free agency officially -- with the expectation that he will re-sign in Los Angeles.\n\nThere have been rumblings that James could get as much as a 3-year deal from the Lakers, as the soon-to-be-40-year-old could play for a few more years. The question is how much of the Lakers money will end up tied up in the oldest player in the NBA, and according to Chris Haynes, James will be \"considering\" taking less than the max to free up the full mid-level exception for the Lakers to add more talent to the roster.\n\nJames would likely need to see a full plan from Rob Pelinka and the front office for how they'll use that money. He also could use this as a further bargaining chip to pressure the Lakers into being more aggressive on the trade market in using their future picks to acquire immediate talent. If he were willing to take less and open up the mid-level to add a quality rotation piece, and the Lakers could add an upgrade on the trade market, that would certainly make them a more formidable contender in the West. {"uri": "2024-06-406040451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "19:53:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T19:53:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T19:26:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/lebron-james-intends-sign-new-deal-lakers-ap-111548338", "title": "LeBron James intends to sign a new deal with the Lakers, AP source says", "body": "LeBron James is not opting into what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and will instead seek a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, according to a person with knowledge of the decision\n\nLeBron James is not opting into what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead will seek a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, a person with knowledge of the decision said Saturday.\n\nThe terms of the new deal could be finalized quickly, said the person, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because neither James nor the Lakers revealed the decision publicly. ESPN, The Athletic and the Los Angeles Times all reported the decision earlier Saturday.\n\nThe move is among those coming just ahead of the NBA's free agency period, which formally opens at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, though at least $1.2 billion in contracts already have been agreed upon because of new rules that allowed teams to speak with their own players about new deals -- in many situations -- starting on the day after the NBA Finals.\n\nAmong those already having agreed to deals that cannot be finalized until the new league year opens on July 6: Toronto teammates Scottie Barnes and Immanuel Quickley, Miami's Bam Adebayo, Indiana's Pascal Siakam, and New York's OG Anunoby.\n\nIt was expected that LeBron James would technically be a free agent. It's also been expected that he would stay with the Lakers.\n\nThe Lakers selected Bronny James -- LeBron James' oldest son -- on Thursday in the second round of the draft, putting them in position to have the first on-court father-son duo in NBA history. And with a new deal, it's even possible that LeBron James could sign for a lower number than he could have commanded to give the Lakers additional financial flexibility for other moves.\n\nLeBron James is a four-time champion and is about $20 million shy of becoming the first player in league history to top $500 million in on-court earnings. Add in his many off-court ventures and investments, and his net worth has been presumed to be more than $1 billion for some time now.\n\nHe'll turn 40 in December and will tie Vince Carter this season in terms of most seasons played in NBA history; the 2024-25 campaign will be James' 22nd in the league. {"uri": "2024-06-405654388", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:45:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:45:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T07:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/jun/29/lebron-is-staying-in-la-now-right/?sports", "title": "LeBron is staying in LA now, right?", "body": "EL SEGUNDO, Calif. -- Three days after LeBron James' podcast partner became the Los Angeles Lakers' head coach, the team drafted his oldest son, Bronny.\n\nUnless they rename the franchise after him next, it's difficult to think of anything more the Lakers could do to make sure the top scorer in NBA history stays with them for the rest of his matchless career.\n\nAlthough James' future still won't be a sure thing until he formally decides where he'll play next season, the Lakers' addition of his 19-year-old son in the second round of the draft Thursday seems to make it extraordinarily unlikely LeBron will be anywhere but Los Angeles in the fall.\n\n\"The biggest moments in sports happen with the Lakers,\" General Manager Rob Pelinka said. \"That's how we're built, and we're excited to see this story unfold.\"\n\nLeBron and Bronny -- LeBron James Jr., that is --\n\nwould be the first father and son to play in the NBA at the same time, let alone on the same team. If LeBron Sr. picks up his $51.4 million player option for next season, he would guarantee he'll get to take his son to work in the fall.\n\nWith their two major moves this week, the Lakers have made it clear they're determined to stick with James as their centerpiece and leader through his record-tying 22nd NBA season this fall and beyond.\n\nLos Angeles' new coach is JJ Redick, who hosted the \"Mind the Game\" podcast with James this year. Redick is a 15-year NBA veteran who has never coached an adult basketball game, yet the Lakers quickly made the unusual choice of hiring the broadcaster after Dan Hurley turned them down. Pelinka didn't deny that Redick's compatibility with James was a plus.\n\nThe Lakers then used the 55th overall pick on Bronny, who put up modest statistics in his only year of college at Southern Cal.\n\nPelinka and the Lakers scouted Bronny James extensively, and he performed solidly at the pre-draft camp and again in a workout at the Lakers' training complex, which was followed by a meeting with Pelinka. Pelinka said he never even asked Bronny what he thought about the potential pressure of playing alongside his father -- something that even LeBron has said Bronny wasn't necessarily eager to do.\n\n\"We really kept the draft process to Bronny being a Laker, and what we felt like we needed to do to help him become great,\" Pelinka said. \"We didn't talk a lot about that, just because (we) wanted to respect his dad's decision as a free agent, so that wasn't really something that came up.\"\n\nJames could pick up his option for 2024-25, or he could sign a new extension for even more money. He could get a maximum threeyear, $162 million deal that would give him the longest career in NBA history if he played out the contract.\n\nEither option would likely be just fine with Lakers Owner Jeanie Buss, who showed a similarly passionate loyalty to Kobe Bryant when she pushed to give him a $48.5 million extension for the final two seasons of his career despite his growing injury problems.\n\nBronny likely doesn't the get Lakers closer to winning now, but their choice with the 17th overall pick just might: Dalton Knecht, the high-scoring Tennessee wing who won the SEC Player of the Year award, appears to be one of the most pro-ready players in the draft, and not just because he's already 23 years old.\n\n\"In my mind, I thought there's no way a player that skilled would be available to us (at No. 17),\" Pelinka said.\n\nPelinka has repeatedly tried to keep fan expectations low for a major player addition to a team that lost to Denver in the first round of the postseason, instead targeting incremental improvements to the core around James and Anthony Davis -- along with a potential upgrade on the bench from Redick's innovative basketball mind.", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-405488229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "05:42:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T05:42:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T05:41:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://sports.inquirer.net/572323/nba-lakers-clearly-hope-to-lock-down-lebron-for-good-next", "title": "NBA: Lakers clearly hope to lock down LeBron for good next", "body": "EL SEGUNDO, California -- Three days after LeBron James' podcast partner became the Los Angeles Lakers' head coach, the NBA team drafted James' oldest son, Bronny.\n\nUnless they rename the franchise after him next, it's difficult to think of anything more the Lakers could do to make sure the top scorer in NBA history stays with them for the rest of his matchless career.\n\nWell, short of actually acquiring a third superstar for James after years of trying.\n\nREAD: Bronny James, LeBron's son, picked by Lakers in NBA Draft\n\nAlthough LeBron's future still won't be a sure thing until he formally decides where he'll play next season, the Lakers' addition of his 19-year-old son in the second round of the draft Thursday seems to make it extraordinarily unlikely LeBron will be anywhere but Los Angeles in the fall.\n\n\"The biggest moments in sports happen with the Lakers,\" general manager Rob Pelinka said. \"That's how we're built, and we're excited to see this story unfold.\"\n\nLeBron and Bronny -- LeBron James Jr., that is -- would be the first father and son to play in the NBA at the same time, let alone on the same team. If LeBron Sr. picks up his $51.4 million player option for next season this week, he would guarantee he'll get to take his son to work in the fall.\n\nPelinka was careful not to get ahead of himself while triumphantly discussing Bronny's potential, but the GM acknowledged that a father-son pairing in purple and gold was \"something that could be magical.\"\n\n\"We know and have to respect, of course, that LeBron has a decision about his opt-out,\" Pelinka said. \"I'm sure he and his family and his agent will deliberate what they're going to do there, and he has freedom to decide whatever is best for him and his family. But if it worked out that he was on our team next season, NBA history could be made, and NBA history should be make in a Lakers uniform.\"\n\nREAD: LeBron James wants to retire a Laker but has no NBA exit timetable\n\nWith their two major moves this week, the Lakers have made it clear they're determined to stick with LeBron as their centerpiece and leader through his record-tying 22nd NBA season this fall and beyond.\n\nLos Angeles' new coach is JJ Redick, who hosted the \"Mind the Game\" podcast with LeBron this year. Redick is a 15-year NBA veteran who has never coached an adult basketball game, yet the Lakers quickly made the unusual choice of hiring the broadcaster after Dan Hurley turned them down -- and Pelinka didn't deny that Redick's compatibility with LeBron was a plus.\n\nThe Lakers then used the 55th overall pick on Bronny, who put up modest statistics in his only year of college at Southern California. Bronny James is undeniably talented, but an identical player with a different name would have been less likely to be drafted.\n\nPelinka and the Lakers scouted Bronny James extensively, and he performed solidly at the pre-draft camp and again in a workout at the Lakers' training complex, which was followed by a meeting with Pelinka. Pelinka said he never even asked Bronny what he thought about the potential pressure of playing alongside his father -- something that even LeBron has said Bronny wasn't necessarily eager to do.\n\nREAD: Lakers coach JJ Redick still hopes to create great content with LeBron\n\n\"We really kept the draft process to Bronny being a Laker, and what we felt like we needed to do to help him become great,\" Pelinka said. \"We didn't talk a lot about that, just because (we) wanted to respect his dad's decision as a free agent, so that wasn't really something that came up.\"\n\nThat decision feels ever more like a formality now, depending on how LeBron decides to do it. The 20-time All-Star and four-time NBA champion has spoken repeatedly over the years of his desire to play a season with his son, and now the dream is a signature away from reality.\n\nLeBron could pick up his option for 2024-25, or he could sign a new extension for even more money. He could get a maximum three-year, $162 million deal that would give him the longest career in NBA history if he played out the contract.\n\nEither option would likely be just fine with Lakers owner Jeanie Buss, who showed a similarly passionate loyalty to Kobe Bryant when she pushed to give him a $48.5 million extension for the final two seasons of his career despite his growing injury problems.\n\nBronny likely doesn't the get Lakers closer to winning now, but their choice with the 17th overall pick just might: Dalton Knecht, the high-scoring Tennessee wing who won the SEC Player of the Year award, appears to be one of the most pro-ready players in the draft, and not just because he's already 23 years old.\n\n\"In my mind, I thought there's no way a player that skilled would be available to us (at No. 17),\" Pelinka said.\n\nPelinka has repeatedly tried to keep fan expectations low for a major player addition to a team that lost to Denver in the first round of the postseason, instead targeting incremental improvements to the core around LeBron and Anthony Davis -- along with a potential upgrade on the bench from Redick's innovative basketball mind.\n\n\"We've explored every upgrade we could to make our team better,\" Pelinka said. \"Trades in general have just because more difficult because of the new CBA system, and so there's less access to making those big moves than maybe there was under the old system. But it didn't keep us from trying to look at everything, and ways to put ourselves in a position to be better.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer"}, {"uri": "2024-06-406009947", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "18:49:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T18:49:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T17:33:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2024/06/29/lebron-james-free-agency-lakers-contract/74209464007/", "title": "LeBron James to free agency after declining Los Angeles Lakers contract option", "body": "USA TODAY Sports' Jeff Zillgitt breaks down the historic move by the Los Angeles Lakers, drafting Bronny James to form the leagues first father-son duo.\n\nLeBron James has declined the player option on the final season of his contract with the Los Angeles Lakers, making him a free agent when free agency begins Sunday, a person familiar with the decision told USA TODAY Sports.\n\nThe person requested anonymity because he was not authorized to speak publicly about James' plans.\n\nDespite the opt-out, it's expected that James will re-sign with the Lakers - especially after they selected his son Bronny with the 55th overall pick in the second round of the NBA draft Thursday.\n\nJames, who turns 40 on Dec. 30, could've exercised his player option and played the final year of his contract with the Lakers in 2024-25 for $51.4 million.\n\nIf James wants to stay a Laker - and he said as much at All-Star Weekend in February when asked by USA TODAY Sports - and have control over his future, opting out and re-signing with the Lakers on a three-year, $162 million deal is the best option.\n\nHe can include a no-trade clause in a new deal, which would silence any talk about the Lakers sending James to another team.\n\n\"I am a Laker, and I am happy and been very happy being a Laker the last six years, and hopefully it stays that way,\" he told USA TODAY Sports in February. \"But I don't have the answer to how long it is or which uniform I'll be in. Hopefully it is with the Lakers. It's a great organization and so many greats. But we'll see. I don't know how it's going to end (NBA playing career), but it's coming. It's coming, for sure.\"\n\nIf James wants to play elsewhere, he can get a three-year contract worth $157.5 million. Now, there aren't many teams with the kind of cap space available to sign James at the salary he wants. His agent Rich Paul, the CEO of Klutch Sports, shot down the idea of James signing a minimum contract to play for a contender. If James wants to remain on a competitive team, that narrows his options outside of the Lakers.\n\nHe averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists, 7.3 rebounds and 1.3 steals and shot 54% from the field and a career-high 41% on 3-pointers in 71 games in 2023-24 as he made the All-Star team for the 20th consecutive season and earned his 20th All-NBA selection.\n\nThe Lakers were eliminated from the playoffs by the Denver Nuggets for the second consecutive season - the Western Conference finals last season and first round this season.\n\nJames performed well in the playoffs, scoring at least 26 points in the five games, including 30 in Game 4 and 30 points, 11 assists, nine rebounds and four steals in Game 5, and shooting better than 50% from the field. But the gap between the two teams was exposed by Denver's second-half execution and the Lakers' slim margin of error.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA Today"}, Friday by the Lakers, and is set to become part of the NBA's first father-son duo alongside his 39-year-old dad.\n\nThe Lakers revealed on Saturday that Bronny would wear Lakers jersey number nine and his uniform would have \"James Jr.\" on the back.\n\nThe club has said they want to re-sign the elder James, a four-time NBA Most Valuable Player, and could swing a deal with him that would provide James has expressed a desire to play alongside his son, and the duo would become the league's first father-son duo to be on the court together.\n\nBronny James' addition to the team made James' return seem more likely with the dream of playing on the same team with his son a step closer to reality. James could pick up his option for 2024-25, or he could sign a new extension for even more money. He could get a maximum three-year, $162 million deal that would give him the longest career in NBA history if he played out the contract.\n\nEither option would likely be just fine with Lakers owner Jeanie Buss, who showed a similarly passionate loyalty to Kobe Bryant when she pushed to give him a $48.5 million extension for the final two seasons of his career despite his growing injury problems.\n\nJames averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds in 71 games last season before the Lakers' first-round playoff exit against the Denver Nuggets. {"uri": "8201845594", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "18:10:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T18:10:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T18:10:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.businessupturn.com/trending/why-lebron-james-opted-out-of-his-contract-with-lakers/", "title": "Why LeBron James opted out of his contract with Lakers | Business Upturn", "body": "LeBron James, the iconic NBA player, is set to make a significant move by opting out of his contract with the Los Angeles Lakers, a decision that will see him enter free agency along with other players at 6 p.m. ET on Sunday. This move comes despite James initially facing a $51.4 million player option, indicating his intent to explore new opportunities in the league.\n\nAt 37 years old and entering his remarkable 22nd NBA season, James has defied age with his enduring athleticism and skill on the court. While retirement rumors have surfaced in recent years, particularly as he nears the twilight of his career, James has consistently shown determination to continue playing, especially driven by the prospect of sharing the NBA court with his son, Bronny James.\n\nThe potential of playing alongside Bronny, who is beginning to make his mark in basketball, adds a deeply personal dimension to LeBron's decision-making process. It raises questions about whether LeBron would forego the chance to team up with his son, a scenario that has captured the imagination of basketball fans worldwide.\n\nAs James navigates this pivotal career moment, his decision will undoubtedly hinge on various factors, including team dynamics, competitive aspirations, and personal goals. Whatever path he chooses in free agency, LeBron James's legacy as one of the greatest players in NBA history remains secure, shaping the league and inspiring generations of basketball enthusiasts.\n\nLeBron James is expected to sign a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, according to reports from The Athletic's Shams Charania. Despite potential overtures from other teams, this decision aligns with recent developments such as the Lakers drafting his son, Bronny James, and appointing his close friend JJ Redick as head coach.\n\nBut why would LeBron opt out of his current contract at all? There are several strategic advantages for him in doing so.\n\nInstead of playing out the final season of his current contract worth $51.4 million, LeBron can negotiate a new three-year deal with the Lakers valued at $162 million. This not only provides a slight increase in earnings for the 2024-25 season but also offers him more long-term security through his potential 24th NBA season.\n\nMoreover, a new contract in free agency would enable LeBron to secure a no-trade clause, a valuable provision that ensures he cannot be traded without his consent. While it's unlikely the Lakers would trade him without his approval anyway, having a no-trade clause adds an extra layer of security and control over his future.\n\nAdditionally, LeBron's contract negotiations could create flexibility for the Lakers. Reports suggest he might seek to open up a mid-level exception, which would allow the team to bolster their roster with additional talent.\n\nLeBron's foray into free agency could also serve as a catalyst for the Lakers to further enhance their roster. If he perceives deficiencies in the team's makeup, LeBron could entertain offers from other teams, potentially forcing Lakers' GM Rob Pelinka to make moves to strengthen the squad.\n\nIt's not unusual for LeBron to enter free agency even when there's little chance of him leaving his current team. He previously opted out of his contract with the Cleveland Cavaliers in 2015 and 2016, despite minimal speculation of him departing Cleveland. This strategic move gives him leverage in negotiations and ensures he can maximize his earnings and team benefits.\n\nDespite the uncertainty surrounding LeBron entering free agency, Lakers fans need not panic. Given recent franchise maneuvers and LeBron's established relationship with the team, it would be surprising to see the NBA legend depart Los Angeles. His potential new contract not only secures his financial future but also reinforces his role in shaping the Lakers' competitive strategy for the coming seasons.", "source": {"uri": Paul told ESPN that he will look to complete a deal with the Lakers for James before Team USA camp opens up.\n\nL.A. drafted James' eldest son, Bronny James, with the No. 55 pick in the second round of the NBA draft Thursday.\n\nJames averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds in 71 games this past season -- the most games he has played in six seasons with the franchise. He shot 54% from the field and a career-best 41% from 3 as he was named to the All-NBA third team and became the first player in league history to surpass 40,000 points.\n\nDavis, who has played five of those six seasons with James in L.A., said he has purposefully not put pressure on James regarding his decision this offseason. The two will pair up in the Paris Olympics this summer, too.\n\n\"I'm just respecting his space,\" Davis told ESPN this week. \"I know we'll be together all summer and I know if he decides to do something -- whether stay with the Lakers, opt in or opt out and re-sign or opt out and choose a different path, I know he'll tell me before he makes any [official] decision just because we have that relationship. James has expressed a desire to play alongside his son, and the duo would become the league's first father-son duo to be on the court together.\n\nBronny James' addition to the team made James' return seem more likely with the dream of playing on the same team with his son a step closer to reality. James could pick up his option for 2024-25, or he could sign a new extension for even more money. He could get a maximum three-year, $162 million deal that would give him the longest career in NBA history if he played out the contract.\n\nEither option would likely be just fine with Lakers owner Jeanie Buss, who showed a similarly passionate loyalty to Kobe Bryant when she pushed to give him a $48.5 million extension for the final two seasons of his career despite his growing injury problems.\n\nJames averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds in 71 games last season before the Lakers' first-round playoff exit against the Denver Nuggets.
