{"uri": "8202685372", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "11:33:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T11:33:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T11:32:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.sunstar.com.ph/network/lebron-seeks-new-deal-with-lakers", "title": "LeBron seeks new deal with Lakers", "body": "NEW DEAL. LeBron James did not exercise his option to accept what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead is seeking a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, an AP source said. / AP\n\nLEBRON James is going to move toward a new contract with the Los Angeles Lakers. Paul George and Klay Thompson may simply be on the move to new teams.\n\nAnd the NBA's free agency period, which officially starts Sunday, suddenly has some intrigue.\n\nJames did not exercise his option to accept what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead is seeking a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, a person with knowledge of the decision said Saturday.\n\nThe terms of the new deal could be finalized quickly, said the person, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because neither James nor the Lakers revealed the decision publicly. ESPN, The Athletic and the Los Angeles Times all reported the decision earlier Saturday.\n\nMeanwhile, George made a similar decision, the nine-time All-Star choosing to not opt-in for what would have been a $48.8 million contract this coming season with the Los Angeles Clippers -- a team that he's spent the past five years with, averaging 23 points per game. He'll become a free agent and is planning to talk to the Clippers about a new deal and also intends to hear pitches from Orlando and Philadelphia, plus potentially others, a person briefed on George's plans told AP on Saturday night.\n\nSaturday's moves came just ahead of the NBA's free agency period, which formally opens at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, though at least $1.2 billion in contracts already have been agreed upon because of new rules that allowed teams to speak with their own players about new deals -- in many situations -- starting on the day after the NBA Finals.\n\nAmong those already having agreed to deals that cannot be finalized until the new league year opens on July 6: Toronto teammates Scottie Barnes and Immanuel Quickley, Miami's Bam Adebayo, Indiana's Pascal Siakam, and New York's OG Anunoby.\n\nIt was expected that James would technically be a free agent. It's also been expected that he would stay with the Lakers.\n\nThe Lakers selected Bronny James -- LeBron James' oldest son -- on Thursday in the second round of the draft, putting them in position to have the first on-court father-son duo in NBA history. And with a new deal, it's even possible that LeBron James could sign for a lower number than he could have commanded to give the Lakers additional financial flexibility for other moves.\n\n\"He is prioritizing a roster improvement,\" James' agent, Klutch Sports CEO Rich Paul, told ESPN on Saturday. \"He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.\"\n\nLeBron James is a four-time champion and is about $20 million shy of becoming the first player in league history to top $500 million in on-court earnings. Add in his many off-court ventures and investments, and his net worth has been presumed to be more than $1 billion for some time now.\n\nHe'll turn 40 in December and will tie Vince Carter this season in terms of most seasons played in NBA history; the 2024-25 campaign will be James' 22nd in the league. He averaged 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds and 8.3 assists last season -- as the oldest active player in the league.\n\nAnd if he's going to leave money on the table, he's going to want a player who can help the Lakers contend for a title again. Among the Lakers' potential targets: Golden State's Klay Thompson, a free agent who could be on the move for the first time in his career.\n\nThompson, a starter on all four of the Warriors' championship teams of this era and half of the famed \"Splash Brothers\" duo alongside 3-point king Stephen Curry, has spent all 13 of his NBA years with Golden State. And his status -- will he go back to the Warriors or not? -- is one of the biggest questions that'll be answered in the coming days. It may not be financially possible for Golden State to retain Thompson.\n\n\"We want him back. We've said that all along,\" Warriors general manager Mike Dunleavy said on June 24. \"Hopefully he'll come back. But as far as the specifics and discussions and those types of things, I think it's important to keep in-house and that stuff. James is expected to re-sign with the Lakers and, according to Yahoo Sports, it could come with a hometown discount.\n\nJames is eligible to sign a three-year, $162 million max deal with the Lakers, but in order for Los Angeles to use its full mid-level exception -- worth approximately $13 million under the new CBA -- James would have to take at least a $20 million pay cut. If James doesn't take a pay cut, the Lakers will enter the offseason over the first apron of the salary cap, which would limit how much they can spend and send out in a potential trade.\n\nJames has only taken a pay cut once before: in 2010, when he, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh all took less money to team up on the Miami Heat. James signed a two-year, $68.6 million deal, which was $15 million less than the maximum a team could offer him in free agency.\n\nThis time around, James' incentive to take a pay cut would be to spend the twilight years of his career on a true contender. {"uri": "8202585175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "10:00:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T10:00:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T09:59:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/lebron-james-opts-out-of-lakers-contract-days-after-la-drafted-son-bronny-heres-what-the-nba-legend-is-planning-ahead-101719737901917.html", "title": "LeBron James opts out of Lakers contract days after LA drafted son Bronny: Here's what the NBA legend is planning ahead", "body": "LeBron James has opted out of the final year of his deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, his agent Rich Paul of Klutch Sports told ESPN.\n\nThe 39-year-old NBA star was expected to turn in his final decision about the contract worth $51.4 million by 5 pm ET Saturday, which he ultimately declined. However, he's not quite kicking the purple and gold colours to the curb yet.\n\nHis decision comes two days after the team drafted his eldest, Bronny James, at the 2024 NBA Draft. LeBron and Bronny made history, becoming the first father-son duo to be active in the league at the same time. The celebratory achievement made them teammates with the Lakers.\n\nAlso read | New York City joins India's T20 World Cup party: Watch Desi community go wild in goosebump-inducing video\n\nAs of now, LeBron has considered stepping out of the spotlight, but staying with the team in other ways, allowing his son his moment to shine in the big league. Paul also reiterated this sentiment, asserting that the James family combo would not be a package deal. He emphasised that LeBron was \"off\" the \"idea\" of them playing on the team together since he was more focussed on his son's growth in the NBA.\n\nA bigger game plan is brewing in James' mind, as explained by his agent on Saturday: \"He is prioritising a roster improvement. He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.\"\n\nAlthough James has opted out of his current contract with the Lakers, he's expected to stick around with the team and take a pay cut from his original contract. Either way, he's expected to share the Lakers colours with his son one way or another.\n\nAlso read | Meghan Markle 'ordered Prince Harry to ignore' David Beckham at Invictus Games; 4 years later, he got revenge\n\nIn the meantime, James is also open to making a financial sacrifice if the team is able to entice a veteran playmaker like James Harden or Klay Thompson or an established force to reckon with like Jonas Valanciunas to play alongside the team.\n\nWith Team USA's training camp for the Summer Paris Olympics just a week away, Paul told ESPN that the NBA's all-time scoring leader intends for this deal to be finalised before his focus drifts away to the pressing national team matters.\n\nLeBron James joined the LA Lakers in 2018, following which he won his fourth NBA title with the team in 2020. This latest report regarding the team's roster switch-up has emerged just as the player has completed his 21st season. At 39, he averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds in 71 games this season. With a career-high shooting record, he became the first player in NBA history to surpass 40,000 points.\n\nAs for James' son, Bronny went into cardiac arrest last year before kicking off his collegiate career; he was later diagnosed with a congenital heart defect. According to The Associated Press, he was eventually cleared to play in the league. In June 2024, he became the Lakers' choice at No. 55.\n\nBronny is early in his basketball development, and, so far, has had an underwhelming season at USC with 4.8 points, 36% shooting, 2.8 He shot 54% from the field and a career-best 41% from 3 as he was named to the All-NBA third team and became the first player in league history to surpass 40,000 points.\n\nLakers star big man Anthony Davis, who has played five of those six seasons with James in L.A., said he has purposefully not put pressure on James regarding his decision this offseason. The two will pair up in the Paris Olympics this summer, too.\n\n\"I'm just respecting his space,\" Davis told ESPN this week. \"I know we'll be together all summer and I know if he decides to do something -- whether stay with the Lakers, opt in or opt out and re-sign or opt out and choose a different path, I know he'll tell me before he makes any [official] decision just because we have that relationship. According to James' agent, Rich Paul, via ESPN's Dave McMenamin, the NBA legend is prioritizing roster improvement in the offseason.\n\nThat means James will sit down with the Lakers and come up with a new contract that will help the team potentially land an impact player. The final year was worth $51.4 million for next season.\n\nSome speculated if James would consider leaving the Lakers, but those concerns went out the window the moment the organization selected his son, Bronny James, with the No. 55 overall pick in the 2024 NBA draft.\n\n\"He is prioritizing a roster improvement. He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster,\" Paul said, per McMenamin.\n\nThe Lakers lost in the playoffs for a second straight year to the Denver Nuggets. They avoided being swept for a consecutive season, but they did drop a 4-1 series loss in a failed effort against a Nuggets team that looked superior to them in every way.\n\nThe Western Conference isn't getting any easier with multiple young and hungry teams on the rise, including the Minnesota Timberwolves and Oklahoma City Thunder.\n\nSure, the Lakers could make the playoffs, but it's hard to envision them competing for a championship without some additional firepower. James turns 40 years old in December, and Anthony Davis' health will always be a question.\n\nThere was a time when the two superstars were all that was needed to run roughshod over the rest of the NBA, but those days are long gone.\n\nStill, what James has continued to do at age 39 is nothing short of amazing. in historic draft", "body": "LeBron James and son Bronny team up for the LA Lakers in historic draft\n\nBronny James was selected by the Los Angeles Lakers in the second round of the NBA draft on Thursday, bringing his father LeBron one step closer to fulfilling his long-held dream of playing alongside his son.\n\nBronny, 19, was informed of the Lakers decision with a phone call from general manager Rob Pelinka while his dad gave an emotional champagne toast to family and friends when they received the news at a restaurant in New York, ESPN reported.\n\nBronny and LeBron will be the first father-son duo to play in the league at the same time and on the same team and while Bronny is not expected to log significant minutes in his rookie season, it will no doubt be a special moment when they appear together for the first time on the NBA hardwood.\n\n\"Family business,\" the Lakers posted on X alongside old and current pictures of Bronny and LeBron.\n\nBronny posted a photo of himself in a Lakers jersey on Instagram and Lakers great Magic Johnson congratulated Bronny and called his selection with the 55th pick of the draft a \"historic moment\" on X.\n\nLeBron was aged 19 and the reigning NBA Rookie of the Year when his now-wife Savannah gave birth to LeBron Raymone \"Bronny\" James Jr. in Akron, Ohio in 2004.\n\nBronny attracted enormous attention as a high school player at Sierra Canyon School in Los Angeles and in his senior year was joined by his younger brother Bryce, a 17-year-old who could also potentially play in the NBA one day.\n\nLast summer Bronny suffered a cardiac arrest while training with the University of Southern California (USC) basketball team and was placed in intensive care.\n\nHe was cleared to return to the team in November and went on to average 4.8 points, 2.8 rebounds and 2.1 assists per game playing guard in his lone season with the Trojans. There was some speculation that another team with a higher pick might swoop in and take Bronny before the Lakers, either to entice LeBron to switch teams or to simply mess with the Lakers plans.\n\nBut doing so would risk raising the ire of Rich Paul, the powerful NBA agent who represents Bronny, LeBron and many top tier players. LeBron, the league's all-time leading scorer and a four-time champion, turns 40 in December and is entering into the 22nd season of his legendary career.\n\nThe Lakers, who fell in the first round of the NBA playoffs in April, have their work cut out for them in the competitive Western Conference next season with first time head coach JJ Redick at the helm.\n\nFans could get their first look at If James wants to stay a Laker - and he said as much at All-Star Weekend in February when asked by USA TODAY Sports - and have control over his future, opting out and re-signing with the Lakers on a three-year, $162 million deal is the best option.\n\nHe can include a no-trade clause in a new deal, which would silence any talk about the Lakers sending James to another team.\n\n\"I am a Laker, and I am happy and been very happy being a Laker the last six years, and hopefully it stays that way,\" he told USA TODAY Sports in February. \"But I don't have the answer to how long it is or which uniform I'll be in. Hopefully it is with the Lakers. It's a great organization and so many greats. But we'll see. I don't know how it's going to end (NBA playing career), but it's coming. It's coming, for sure.\"\n\nIf James wants to play elsewhere, he can get a three-year contract worth $157.5 million. Now, there aren't many teams with the kind of cap space available to sign James at the salary he wants. His agent Rich Paul, the CEO of Klutch Sports, shot down the idea of James signing a minimum contract to play for a contender. If James wants to remain on a competitive team, that narrows his options outside of the Lakers.\n\nHe averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists, 7.3 rebounds and 1.3 steals and shot 54% from the field and a career-high 41% on 3-pointers in 71 games in 2023-24 as he made the All-Star team for the 20th consecutive season and earned his 20th All-NBA selection.\n\nThe Lakers were eliminated from the playoffs by the Denver Nuggets for the second consecutive season - Western Conference finals last season and first round this season.\n\nJames performed well in the playoffs, scoring at least 26 points in the five games, including 30 in Game 4 and 30 points, 11 assists, nine rebounds and four steals in Game 5, and shooting better than 50% from the field. {"uri": "2024-06-405865582", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "14:49:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T14:49:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T14:05:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://lakersnation.com/lakers-video-rob-pelinka-jj-redick-give-bronny-james-news-of-being-drafted/", "title": "Lakers Video: Rob Pelinka & JJ Redick Give Bronny James News Of Being Drafted", "body": "Leading into the 2024 NBA Draft, it seemed like a foregone conclusion that the Los Angeles Lakers would select Bronny James with the 55th overall pick. And when the time came and the Lakers were on the clock, general manager Rob Pelinka, head coach JJ Redick and the front office made the call to make Bronny a member of the franchise.\n\nBronny, of course, is the son of current Lakers superstar LeBron James and the two will become the first father-son duo to play in the NBA at the same time. And while much of the focus will be on LeBron and Bronny playing together, the day was extremely special for Bronny just to be drafted in the first place.\n\nIt is extremely special for any player to hear their name called on draft night and to receive that call from the team selecting you. That was very much the case for Bronny and the Lakers made sure to capture the moment of Pelinka and Redick making that call to him to let him know the team would be taking him 55th overall:\n\nRegardless of whether some think James was deserving of being drafted, it can not be argued that he has put in a ton of work to get to this point. The amount of pressure on him, being the son of LeBron, is immense and unlike anything any other draft prospect had to deal with and Bronny has handled it all with a ton of grace.\n\nAs Pelinka said, Bronny's work ethic and high character stand out as things the Lakers value. But his skillset is there as well and there was a reason he was a McDonalds All-American in high school. Bronny is a great defender and excellent athlete who has a great feel for the game which shouldn't come as a surprise considering his father.\n\nBronny has put in the work and is deserving of that moment of Pelinka and Redick making that call to let him know he will be a member of the Lakers.\n\nCurrent and former NBA stars congratulate Bronny James being drafted by the Lakers\n\nThe basketball world was able to witness Bronny James being taken 55th overall by the Lakers and many took to social media to congratulate the son of LeBron James on the accomplishment.\n\nCurrent Lakers such as Austin Reaves and Jarred Vanderbilt posted on Instagram while Lakers legend Magic Johnson shared a lengthy post on X. "body": "LeBron James will decline his $51.4 million player option with the Lakers for the 2024-25 season and become an unrestricted free agent, but he is expected to return to the organization on a new contract, The Atheltic reported on Saturday morning.\n\nJames, who turns 40 in December and is entering his 22nd NBA season, had until 2 p.m. on Saturday to decide on the option in his contract as part of the two-year, $99 million contract extension he signed with the Lakers in September 2022.\n\nHe could sign a three-year maximum contract worth approximately $162 million with the Lakers with a 2024-25 salary of approximately $49.9 million once free agency starts at 3 p.m. on Sunday - which the franchise is reportedly willing to offer.\n\nJames could also sign shorter-team deals to become eligible for free agency again in the next couple of offseasons.\n\nHe would be eligible to have a no-trade clause in his new contract with the Lakers since he's been in the NBA for at least eight seasons and the Lakers for at least four.\n\nJames continued to raise the bar in his 21st NBA season, averaging 25.7 points, 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds in 71 games with the Lakers in 2023-24, shooting 54% from the field and 41% on 3-pointers, his record 20th consecutive season averaging at least 25 points.\n\nHis 3-point accuracy was a career-high while his shooting percentage was his best in six seasons as a Laker.\n\nJames became the first player in league history to eclipse 40,000 career points on March 2 against the Denver Nuggets and extended his NBA-record double-digit scoring streak to 1,222 consecutive regular-season games.\n\nIn addition to first-round pick Dalton Knecht, the Lakers drafted James' oldest son, Bronny James, in the second round of the NBA draft.", {"uri": "8202030265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "22:14:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T22:14:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T22:14:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://heavy.com/sports/nba/los-angeles-lakers/lebron-james-opt-out-pay-cut-future/", "title": "LeBron James Sends Strong Message to Lakers After Opting Out", "body": "LeBron James has opted out of the final year with the Los Angeles Lakers and is willing to take a pay cut to return if it means improving the roster.\n\nJames' long-time agent, Rich Paul, spoke to Dave McMenamin of ESPN on Saturday, June 29. He confirmed that the four-time MVP had opted out of player-option, worth $51.4 million. James is willing to reduce his salary -- at least for a year -- if it means adding an impact player.\n\n\"He is prioritizing a roster improvement,\" Paul told ESPN. \"He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.\"\n\nThe goal of James taking less is to open up the full $12.9 million mid-level exception to sign an \"impact player,\" per ESPN. Potential players that James feels match that description are James Harden, Klay Thompson or veteran big man Jonas Valanciunas.\n\nJames has made nearly $480 million on the court during his career. He also has a bevy of off-court ventures, making him one of the most successful athletes ever. James will turn 40 next season and time is running out on winning another championship. He's clearly all-in to make it happen next season.\n\nThe Lakers are on a tight timeline to make something happen. James is set to enter training camp with Team USA next week in preparation for the Olympics, and Paul wants a deal with the Lakers done by then.\n\nIf the Lakers do not land the impact player they desire by then, James will seek a maximum three-year, $162 million contract.\n\n\"If LA cannot find an impact player to sign for the full MLE that would be created by James taking a paycut, James will seek the max,\" McMenamin said. \"There can only be so much patience on James' part: Team USA camp begins a week from today in Las Vegas and he needs a deal before taking the court.\"\n\nJames averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds in 71 games last season with the Lakers. He earned his 20th All-Star nod and was named third-team All-NBA.\n\nDespite opting out, James will likely return to the Lakers. The only question now is the money. He'll have an opportunity to play alongside his son, Bronny James, whom the team selected with the No. 55 overall pick in the second round.\n\nA big part of the championship recipie in LA is Anthony Davis. The star big man has not applied any pressure on James to make a decision.\n\n\"I'm just respecting his space,\" Davis told ESPN. \"I know we'll be together all summer and I know if he decides to do something -- whether stay with the Lakers, opt in or opt out and re-sign or opt out and choose a different path, I know he'll tell me before he makes any [official] decision just because we have that relationship. {"uri": "8201897492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "19:11:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T19:11:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T19:11:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/lebron-james-is-considering-taking-a-paycut-to-help-with-lakers-targets/article_fbcc246f-174f-518e-b374-5995e6049151.html", "title": "LeBron James Is Considering Taking A Paycut To Help With Lakers Targets", "body": "LeBron James, having opted out of his contract, is poised to re-sign with the Los Angeles Lakers. This move comes with significant strategic implications, as James is reportedly considering taking a pay cut to help the Lakers maximize their potential in free agency and the trade market.\n\nBy opting out and potentially signing a new deal at a reduced rate, LeBron could enable the Lakers to utilize the full mid-level exception (MLE), which is approximately $12.8 million. This financial flexibility could be crucial for the Lakers as they look to bolster their roster and contend for another NBA title.\n\nChris Haynes has reported that with LeBron James re-signing, he is contemplating this pay cut to open a pathway for the Lakers to secure the full mid-level exception. This would allow the team to pursue key targets in free agency more aggressively, adding depth and talent to support James and Anthony Davis.\n\nIn addition to LeBron's potential pay cut, the Lakers are also navigating the situation with D'Angelo Russell, who has opted into his contract. The Lakers are reportedly looking to trade Russell, and his $18.7 million expiring contract could be a valuable asset in trade negotiations.\n\nIf LeBron's pay cut is factored in, the Lakers would have even more financial flexibility to execute trades and sign free agents, making them a formidable player in the market.\n\nBrian Windhorst has suggested that LeBron may be willing to take a pay cut for the first time in 15 years.\n\n\"What if LeBron James for the first time in 15 years is willing to take a pay cut? That's right. It's all warm and fuzzy right now that they drafted Bronny... The Lakers could be a player in free agency, use their mid-level exception of about $12 million.\"\n\n\"So it wouldn't surprise me if LeBron waits a little bit of time, even when he's out there as a free agent intending to sign with L.A. to see what kind of contracts might be able to help the Lakers. He might be in the giving mood.\"\n\nThis move would not only demonstrate his commitment to winning but also his willingness to make personal financial sacrifices for the team's success. Windhorst noted the warm atmosphere surrounding the Lakers, especially after drafting LeBron's son, Bronny James, and hiring J.J. Redick as the new head coach. This environment might influence LeBron to take less money to facilitate better team-building opportunities.\n\nIf LeBron does take a pay cut, it would allow the Lakers to utilize the MLE to its fullest, potentially bringing in a high-caliber player who can significantly impact their playoff aspirations. Moreover, the flexibility gained from trading D'Angelo Russell could lead to acquiring another star or key role player, further strengthening the roster.\n\nLeBron James considering a pay cut to help the Lakers acquire the full mid-level exception and trade aggressively is a testament to his commitment to winning. This strategic move could position the Lakers as a major contender in free agency and the trade market, providing them with the tools needed to build a championship-caliber team around James and Davis.\n\nRelated: Los Angeles Lakers Starting Lineup And Bench After Selecting Dalton Knecht And Bronny James\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "8201846544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "18:11:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T18:11:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T18:11:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.si.com/nba/lebron-james-plans-opt-out-re-sign-lakers-report", "title": "LeBron James Plans to Opt Out, Re-Sign With Lakers, per Report", "body": "Apr 29, 2024; Denver, Colorado, USA; Los Angeles Lakers forward LeBron James (23) in the third quarter against the Denver Nuggets during game five of the first round for the 2024 NBA playoffs at Ball Arena. Mandatory Credit: Isaiah J. Downing-USA TODAY Sports / Isaiah J. Downing-USA TODAY Sports\n\nAccording to reports on Saturday, James plans to opt out of the final year of his contract with the Los Angeles Lakers, then work out a new deal with the team. James was due to make $51.4 million if he exercised his player option for the 2024-25 season.\n\nESPN reports the Lakers are \"committed to keeping James with the franchise\" and are willing to offer him a maximum, three-year, $162 million deal. While that is the max deal James is eligible for, the two sides could come to another agreement once they begin negotiating.\n\nJames just finished his sixth season with the Lakers and has maintained an incredible level of play as he has aged. He was named third team All-NBA during the 2023-24 campaign while averaging 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds and 8.3 assists in 35.2 minutes per game. He also shot a career-best 41% from three-point range and made 54% of his shots from the field.\n\nOn Friday, the Lakers deepened James's connection to the franchise by selecting his son Bronny with the 55th pick in the 2024 NBA Draft.\n\nLos Angeles is fully built around James at this point, so it's not shocking the two sides would like to continue their partnership. The Lakers hired his podcast co-host JJ Redick as their new head coach a few days before selecting Bronny in the draft.\n\nThe all-time great appears ready to end his career with the Lakers. The partnership has been successful, as James led the franchise to an NBA title in '20. But during his time in LA, the team has missed the playoffs twice, been eliminated in the first round twice and was swept in the conference finals in '23. Those results likely aren't up to James's standards.\n\nJames appears set to be back with the Lakers. While the decision means James will become a free agent on Sunday for the fourth time in his decorated career, his Lakers future is hardly in doubt given they selected his son in the second round of the NBA Draft on Thursday.\n\nFour-times NBA champion LeBron James has opted out of the final year of his contract with the Los Angeles Lakers but is working on a new deal with the team, according to an ESPN report on Saturday.\n\nWhile the decision means James will become a free agent on Sunday for the fourth time in his decorated career, his Lakers future is hardly in doubt given they selected his son in the second round of the NBA Draft on Thursday. According to ESPN, James opted out of a contract worth $51.4 million for next season to become a free agent eligible to sign a maximum three-year deal with the Lakers worth $162 million.\n\nBut ESPN, which sourced James' agent Rich Paul, said the NBA's all-time leading scorer is willing to work with the Lakers on a deal below the maximum to better position the team to sign an impact player. \"He is prioritizing a roster improvement,\" Paul told ESPN. \"He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.\"\n\nJames had until 5 p.m. ET (2100 GMT) on Saturday to decide whether to opt into his player option for the 2024-25 National Basketball Association season. Reuters was unable to reach Paul for comment while the Lakers did not immediately respond when asked to confirm the ESPN report.\n\nIn six seasons with the Lakers the four-times league MVP has averaged 27 points per game, eight assists and 7.9 rebounds. The Lakers finished seventh in the Western Conference this year with a 47-35 record and went on to lose to the defending champion Denver Nuggets in the first round of the NBA playoffs.\n\n(This story ESPN, The Athletic and the Los Angeles Times all reported the decision earlier Saturday.\n\nThe move is among those coming just ahead of the NBA's free agency period, which formally opens at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, though at least $1.2 billion in contracts already have been agreed upon because of new rules that allowed teams to speak with their own players about new deals -- in many situations -- starting on the day after the NBA Finals.\n\nAmong those already having agreed to deals that cannot be finalized until the new league year opens on July 6: Toronto teammates Scottie Barnes and Immanuel Quickley, Miami's Bam Adebayo, Indiana's Pascal Siakam, and New York's OG Anunoby.\n\nIt was expected that LeBron James would technically be a free agent. And with a new deal, it's even possible that LeBron James could sign for a lower number than he could have commanded to give the Lakers additional financial flexibility for other moves.\n\nLeBron James is a four-time champion and is about $20 million shy of becoming the first player in league history to top $500 million in on-court earnings. According to NBA insiders, James plans to opt out of his current contract and sign a new deal that would reduce his salary by approximately $17 million. This move is intended to free up a full mid-level exception contract, enabling the Lakers to sign a valuable starter or bench contributor, although not a star player.\n\nLeBron's willingness to reduce his salary demonstrates his commitment to strengthening the team's roster. Among the potential targets for the Lakers are Klay Thompson, who is expected to leave the Golden State Warriors, as well as Miles Bridges, Jonas Valanciunas, and Caleb Martin.\n\nJames' decision comes as part of a broader strategy to enhance the Lakers' competitiveness and potentially bring another championship to Los Angeles. {"uri": "8202173059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:13:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:13:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:12:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://fox40.com/sports/ap-sports/ap-lebron-james-intends-to-sign-a-new-deal-with-the-lakers-ap-source-says/", "title": "LeBron James intends to sign a new deal with the Lakers, AP source says", "body": "LeBron James is going to move toward a new contract with the Los Angeles Lakers. Paul George and Klay Thompson may simply be on the move to new teams.\n\nAnd the NBA's free agency period, which officially starts Sunday, suddenly has some intrigue.\n\nJames did not exercise his option to accept what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead is seeking a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, a person with knowledge of the decision said Saturday.\n\nThe terms of the new deal could be finalized quickly, said the person, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because neither James nor the Lakers revealed the decision publicly. ESPN, The Athletic and the Los Angeles Times all reported the decision earlier Saturday.\n\nMeanwhile, George made a similar decision, the nine-time All-Star choosing to not opt-in for what would have been a $48.8 million contract this coming season with the Los Angeles Clippers -- a team that he's spent the past five years with, averaging 23 points per game. He'll become a free agent and is planning to talk to the Clippers about a new deal and also intends to hear pitches from Orlando and Philadelphia, plus potentially others, a person briefed on George's plans told AP on Saturday night.\n\nSaturday's moves came just ahead of the NBA's free agency period, which formally opens at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, though at least $1.2 billion in contracts already have been agreed upon because of new rules that allowed teams to speak with their own players about new deals -- in many situations -- starting on the day after the NBA Finals.\n\nAmong those already having agreed to deals that cannot be finalized until the new league year opens on July 6: Toronto teammates Scottie Barnes and Immanuel Quickley, Miami's Bam Adebayo, Indiana's Pascal Siakam, and New York's OG Anunoby.\n\nIt was expected that James would technically be a free agent. It's also been expected that he would stay with the Lakers.\n\nThe Lakers selected Bronny James -- LeBron James' oldest son -- on Thursday in the second round of the draft, putting them in position to have the first on-court father-son duo in NBA history. And with a new deal, it's even possible that LeBron James could sign for a lower number than he could have commanded to give the Lakers additional financial flexibility for other moves.\n\n\"He is prioritizing a roster improvement,\" James' agent, Klutch Sports CEO Rich Paul, told ESPN on Saturday. \"He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.\"\n\nLeBron James is a four-time champion and is about $20 million shy of becoming the first player in league history to top $500 million in on-court earnings. Add in his many off-court ventures and investments, and his net worth has been presumed to be more than $1 billion for some time now.\n\nHe'll turn 40 in December and will tie Vince Carter this season in terms of most seasons played in NBA history; the 2024-25 campaign will be James' 22nd in the league. He averaged 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds and 8.3 assists last season -- as the oldest active player in the league.\n\nAnd if he's going to leave money on the table, he's going to want a player who can help the Lakers contend for a title again. Among the Lakers' potential targets: Golden State's Klay Thompson, a free agent who could be on the move for the first time in his career.\n\nThompson, a starter on all four of the Warriors' championship teams of this era and half of the famed \"Splash Brothers\" duo alongside 3-point king Stephen Curry, has spent all 13 of his NBA years with Golden State. And his status -- will he go back to the Warriors or not? -- is one of the biggest questions that'll be answered in the coming days. It may not be financially possible for Golden State to retain Thompson.\n\n\"We want him back. We've said that all along,\" Warriors general manager Mike Dunleavy said on June 24. \"Hopefully he'll come back. But as far as the specifics and discussions and those types of things, I think it's important to keep in-house and that stuff. James is expected to re-sign with the Lakers on a new contract. James will have the ability to receive a no-trade clause as part of his contract instead of signing an extension after opting in. James can sign for up to $160 million over three seasons.\n\nChris Haynes reports that James is open to taking less money to allow the Lakers to use the full midlevel exception. use the MLE.\n\nJames will be a free agent for the sixth time in his career following 2010, 2014, 2015, 2016 and 2018.\n\nJames appeared in 71 games last season, averaging 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds {"uri": "2024-06-406109002", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "22:41:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T22:41:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T22:27:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/lakers-news-rich-paul-reveals-lebron-james-priority-for-new-contract", "title": "Rich Paul reveals LeBron James' 'priority' after opting out of Lakers contract", "body": "LeBron James recently opted out of his contract with free agency around the corner. It's expected he'll re-sign with the Los Angeles Lakers. However, Rich Paul, James' agent, reveals that James has one \"priority\" for the franchise to fulfill before he signs a deal.\n\nReports indicate that LeBron James will sign a new contract with the Lakers as long as the front office acquires \"an impact player\" this offseason, according to Dave McMenamin of ESPN. To put it simply, James wants to ensure the roster is up to standards before he signs a new deal.\n\n\"Rich Paul of Klutch Sports told ESPN that LeBron James has officially opted out with L.A. and will work with LAL on his next deal if it means adding an impact player: 'He is prioritizing a roster improvement. He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.'\"\n\nThe Lakers are on a rather short timetable to see this through. LeBron James is preparing for the Summer Olympics and it sounds like the superstar forward \"needs a deal before taking the court.\" McMenamin also reports that if the Lakers are unable to acquire an impact player, then James will demand a full max deal. So, there's a chance LA signs James on a cheaper contract while also picking up a solid player through free agency or trade.\n\n\"If LA cannot find an impact player to sign for the full MLE that would be created by James taking a pay cut, James will seek the max. There can only be so much patience on James' part: Team USA camp begins a week from today in Las Vegas and he needs a deal before taking the court.\"\n\nSo, when it comes down to it, LeBron James is likely to sign a contract with the Lakers no matter what. But the front office has an opportunity to bring in a star-caliber player to improve the roster and still retain James for at least next season. We'll see how it plays out, but the front office must act swiftly.\n\nWho should the Lakers target to please LeBron James?\n\nThere are plenty of options on the table for the Lakers right now. The easiest path to finding another star is through free agency. But we can't rule out a possible trade either. Finding a stud free agent would be the best decision, as the front office wouldn't have to give up any assets like they would in a trade.\n\nWith that said, reports point to three names that LeBron James would be willing to take a pay cut for. Those players are James Harden, Klay Thompson, or Jonas Valan\u010di\u016bnas, per Dave McMenamin of ESPN.\n\n\"The type of player that James would be willing to make a financial sacrifice for would be an established veteran playmaker like James Harden or Klay Thompson, or an established big man to play alongside Anthony Davis -- like Jonas Valan\u010di\u016bnas, sources told ESPN.\"\n\nWe should expect the Lakers to pursue Harden, Thompson, and/or Valan\u010di\u016bnas in the coming days. {"uri": "8202873206", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "14:32:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T14:32:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T14:31:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/lebron-james-willing-to-take-a-16-million-pay-cut-to-help-lakers/article_7dd1798e-6a85-570d-ba5c-49d92b1998f9.html", "title": "LeBron James Willing To Take A $16 Million Pay Cut To Help Lakers", "body": "LeBron James is reportedly willing to take a $16 million pay cut to help the Los Angeles Lakers enhance their roster and compete for another championship. This willingness to reduce his salary showcases James's commitment to building a championship-caliber team around him, even at this stage of his illustrious career.\n\n\"In order for LeBron James to sacrifice enough money to get the Lakers receiving the full midlevel exception, he will have to take $16 million less next season. And that's a lot of money.\"\n\n\"For someone who is 39 years old, that's a lot of money to be given up in a season. But it would take that much to get the Lakers the full midlevel exception.\"\n\n\"If LeBron were to do this, it's not a situation that you gonna use that to bring on a couple of players to try to improve the team by the margins. No.\"\n\n\"It will take a star-level or a borderline star player to accept that midlevel exception, which would be a pay cut for that player. That's what it will take for LeBron to take a pay cut.\"\n\nChris Haynes reported that James's agent, Rich Paul, indicated the pay cut would only happen if it allows the Lakers to acquire an \"impact player.\" The names mentioned include Klay Thompson and James Harden, both of whom would fit the bill but would also require significant pay cuts themselves to join the Lakers under these financial constraints.\n\nJames opted out of his contract with the Lakers, which would have paid him $51.4 million next season. By doing so, he opens the possibility of re-signing at a lower salary, potentially around $33 million for the 2024-25 season.\n\nThis significant pay cut would enable the Lakers to utilize the full non-taxpayer midlevel exception, worth approximately $12.9 million, to sign a high-impact player or a star who could be a game-changer for the team.\n\nJames's decision to take a pay cut is not just about the money; it is about securing the right pieces to make the Lakers a formidable contender. The Lakers have already made strategic moves this offseason, including hiring JJ Redick as head coach, drafting Dalton Knecht, and uniting LeBron with his son, Bronny James, by selecting him with the 55th pick in the NBA Draft.\n\nD'Angelo Russell's decision to opt into his contract provides the Lakers with a valuable trade asset, further enhancing their flexibility in building the roster.\n\nLeBron's potential pay cut is also about setting the right tone and showing his commitment to winning another championship. Despite his age, LeBron remains one of the top talents in the NBA and is driven to secure another title. His willingness to sacrifice financially to improve the team's chances highlights his dedication to the Lakers and his pursuit of greatness.\n\nThis move would not only help the Lakers financially but also potentially bring in the necessary talent to make a deep playoff run. With James willing to take a pay cut, the Lakers are better positioned to pursue and acquire the right pieces to build a championship team, showing that LeBron is not just playing for personal accolades but for the legacy of the franchise.\n\nLeBron James Wants To Have One Last Title Run\n\nLeBron James, one of the greatest players in NBA history, is signaling his desire for one last title run by considering a significant pay cut. This move is driven by his determination to build a competitive squad capable of contending for the championship in his final seasons.\n\nLeBron's commitment to the Lakers is evident in his willingness to sacrifice financially to enhance the team's roster. This decision comes at a pivotal moment in his career as he approaches the twilight of his playing days.\n\nDrafting his son, Bronny James, and the prospect of playing alongside him is a dream come true for LeBron. Not only will it create a unique and historic father-son duo on the court, but it also presents an opportunity for LeBron to achieve another rare feat: winning a championship with his son by his side.\n\nThe Lakers fell short last season, making it to the Western Conference Finals but getting swept by the Denver Nuggets. LeBron understands the challenges ahead, especially in a highly competitive Western Conference.\n\nTeams are continually improving, and the road to a championship is fraught with obstacles. To have a realistic shot at the title, the Lakers need a well-rounded, strong squad that can compete at the highest level.\n\nLeBron's willingness to take a pay cut is a strategic move to allow the Lakers to utilize the full non-taxpayer midlevel exception, thereby enabling them to acquire key players who can make a significant impact. This financial flexibility can help the Lakers target high-caliber talent to bolster their roster.\n\nLeBron's legacy is already cemented with four championships, but his hunger for more success drives him to strive for one last title. This potential final championship run is not just about adding another ring to his collection; it's about securing his legacy, playing alongside his son, and providing the Lakers with another opportunity to achieve greatness.\n\nBy making personal sacrifices and focusing on team-building, LeBron is setting the stage for a memorable and potentially historic final chapter in his illustrious career. The Lakers' front office must now capitalize on this opportunity, assembling a roster that can help LeBron achieve his ultimate goal: one last championship run.\n\nRelated: Klay Thompson Is 'Intrigued' About Playing With LeBron James And The Lakers\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "8202486452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "08:30:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T08:30:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T08:28:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/06/30/lebron-seeking-new-deal-klay-among-potential-lakers-targets/", "title": "LeBron seeking new deal, Klay among potential Lakers targets | The Associated Press", "body": "LEBRON JAMES is going to move toward a new contract with the Los Angeles Lakers. Paul George and Klay Thompson may simply be on the move to new teams.\n\nAnd the NBA's free agency period, which officially starts Sunday, suddenly has some intrigue.\n\nJames did not exercise his option to accept what would have been a $51.4 million contract for this coming season and instead is seeking a new deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, a person with knowledge of the decision said Saturday.\n\nThe terms of the new deal could be finalized quickly, said the person, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because neither James nor the Lakers revealed the decision publicly. ESPN, The Athletic and the Los Angeles Times all reported the decision earlier Saturday.\n\nMeanwhile, George made a similar decision, the nine-time All-Star choosing to not opt-in for what would have been a $48.8 million contract this coming season with the Los Angeles Clippers -- a team that he's spent the past five years with, averaging 23 points per game. He'll become a free agent and is planning to talk to the Clippers about a new deal and also intends to hear pitches from Orlando and Philadelphia, plus potentially others, a person briefed on George's plans told AP on Saturday night.\n\nSaturday's moves came just ahead of the NBA's free agency period, which formally opens at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, though at least $1.2 billion in contracts already have been agreed upon because of new rules that allowed teams to speak with their own players about new deals -- in many situations -- starting on the day after the NBA Finals.\n\nAmong those already having agreed to deals that cannot be finalized until the new league year opens on July 6: Toronto teammates Scottie Barnes and Immanuel Quickley, Miami's Bam Adebayo, Indiana's Pascal Siakam, and New York's OG Anunoby.\n\nIt was expected that James would technically be a free agent. It's also been expected that he would stay with the Lakers.\n\nThe Lakers selected Bronny James -- LeBron James' oldest son -- on Thursday in the second round of the draft, putting them in position to have the first on-court father-son duo in NBA history. And with a new deal, it's even possible that LeBron James could sign for a lower number than he could have commanded to give the Lakers additional financial flexibility for other moves.\n\n\"He is prioritizing a roster improvement,\" James' agent, Klutch Sports CEO Rich Paul, told ESPN on Saturday. \"He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster.\"\n\nLeBron James is a four-time champion and is about $20 million shy of becoming the first player in league history to top $500 million in on-court earnings. Add in his many off-court ventures and investments, and his net worth has been presumed to be more than $1 billion for some time now.\n\nHe'll turn 40 in December and will tie Vince Carter this season in terms of most seasons played in NBA history; the 2024-25 campaign will be James' 22nd in the league. He averaged 25.7 points, 7.3 rebounds and 8.3 assists last season -- as the oldest active player in the league.\n\nAnd if he's going to leave money on the table, he's going to want a player who can help the Lakers contend for a title again. Among the Lakers' potential targets: Golden State's Klay Thompson, a free agent who could be on the move for the first time in his career.\n\nThompson, a starter on all four of the Warriors' championship teams of this era and half of the famed \"Splash Brothers\" duo alongside 3-point king Stephen Curry, has spent all 13 of his NBA years with Golden State. And his status -- will he go back to the Warriors or not? -- is one of the biggest questions that'll be answered in the coming days. It may not be financially possible for Golden State to retain Thompson.\n\n\"We want him back. We've said that all along,\" Warriors general manager Mike Dunleavy said on June 24. \"Hopefully he'll come back. But as far as the specifics and discussions and those types of things, I think it's important to keep in-house and that stuff. George joked about what Bronny will call his dad when they're on the same team, before looking forward to watching Bronny throw a lob for LeBron to alley-oop.\n\n\"I don't know how soon JJ Redick is going to throw Bronny out there. But it'll be cool to see. Just imagine, that Bronny throws a lob to LeBron. LA is going to go crazy... It's just the dynamic of that. Bronny (is) going to be on a little fast break, Bron is trying to chase it down.\"\n\nGeorge added that he is very excited to see Bronny in the NBA, and claimed that he has high potential in the NBA to be a success. George is clearly a believer in the potential of Bronny James.\n\n\"I think so. I'm a fan of Bronny. I think he has NBA potential for sure.\"\n\nBronny James was selected by the Lakers with the 55th overall pick in the 2024 NBA Draft. The Lakers are excited by both the player and the person James proved himself to be, as Lakers GM Rob Pelinka said in the press conference after the second round of the draft.\n\nThe Lakers will probably be sending Bronny to the G League to develop, as he is still quite a raw prospect who needs to develop before he plays regular NBA minutes. But we are very likely to see at least one game where LeBron James and Bronny James are on the court together at the same time.\n\nMany NBA Players Think Highly Of Bronny James\n\nGeorge is far from the only player looking forward to watching Bronny James in the NBA. Recently, Draymond Green recently spoke on his podcast and noted that Bronny will be a success in the NBA because of his genetics, and added that being the son of LeBron James has given him some great physical gifts but also a solid basketball IQ.\n\n\"We all know what Bronny went through a year ago. To go through that and make it back from that and be in the NBA within a year, is a testament to his drive and work ethic.\"\n\n\"I think Bronny is going to end up being a better pro than a lot of these players in the 2024 draft because he has the athleticism, has the basketball IQ, plays the game the right way. I think he's going to be a good shooter in the NBA. I'm just going to take the bet that this kid works hard, which he does, and he's got LeBron James' DNA. And then you watch him play, and he's a good basketball player.\"\n\nBronny will always have known about the struggles he would have if he ever made it to the NBA. With his father being one of the greatest players of all time, there was never going to be a situation where Bronny wasn't compared to him. But he should focus on his own game and development, and try to be his own player.\n\nLakers fans will get their first glimpse at Bronnyn James next month, as the NBA Summer League takes place in Las Vegas. James will be looking to impress JJ Redick and the rest of the Lakers staff ahead of the next season to earn some minutes with the team next season.\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9692325", "eventUri": "eng-9692325", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2156862745098038, "wgt": 172, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8202131532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "01:01:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T01:01:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T01:01:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5603722/2024/06/29/lebron-james-lakers-free-agent-rumors/", "title": "LeBron James is back, and now Lakers must provide him some meaningful roster upgrades", "body": "The Los Angeles Lakers' 2024 offseason is off to an encouraging start.\n\nThey hired a bright young coach in JJ Redick. They landed top-10 prospect Dalton Knecht with the No. 17 pick in the 2024 NBA Draft. They made history by uniting LeBron James with his eldest son, Bronny James, with their No. 55 selection. D'Angelo Russell, possibly the biggest domino of their offseason, opted in, giving them a mid-sized expiring contract to potentially trade.\n\nThen, on Saturday morning, nearly five hours ahead of a 5 p.m. ET deadline, LeBron James opted out of his contract with the intention of re-signing with the Lakers, according to The Athletic's Shams Charania. The Athletic previously reported the Lakers want James to return and were open to offering him whatever type of contract he prefers.\n\nJames opting out is another win for the Lakers, as James opting out instead of exercising his $51.4 million player option for next season could save the Lakers at least $1.5 million on their cap sheet. (The trade-off for James is he's eligible to add a no-trade clause to his contract, which would allow him to control his future.)\n\nJames may be willing to take an even steeper pay cut on top of that if it allows the Lakers to open up the non-taxpayer mid-level exception (worth approximately $12.9 million) for the right types of players, according to Bleacher Report. James' agent, Klutch Sports CEO Rich Paul, told ESPN his client would only be willing to take a discount for an \"impact player,\" with James Harden, Klay Thompson and Jonas Valan\u010di\u016bnas as reported names who'd fit the bill. The nontaxpayer midlevel exception would be a significant pay cut for Harden and Thompson, in particular.\n\nHowever, there is mutual interest between the Lakers and Thompson, as The Athletic's Shams Charania and Anthony Slater first reported. Thompson, a Southern California native, is the son of Mychal Thompson, who played for the Showtime Lakers from 1987 through 1991 and is the team's current radio color commentator. The younger Thompson, 34, is a four-time NBA champion and one of the greatest shooters of all time -- arguably the second-best behind only his current teammate, Stephen Curry. Thompson has spent his 12 pro seasons with the Golden State Warriors, but the relationship has fractured to the point where Thompson is likely to leave. The Lakers, Dallas Mavericks and LA Clippers are all pursuing him.\n\nIf James takes a discount for the Lakers to access their full nontaxpayer midlevel exception, the Lakers will be hard-capped at the first apron of $178.7 million. That means James would have to take a $16-plus million discount, with his starting salary at about just over $33 million for the 2024-25 season. The most likely pay cut scenario would be James signing a two-year deal with a player option for 2025-26, allowing him to opt out in 2025 and re-sign for more money, according to league sources. The Lakers could also perform a smaller salary-dump trade (or two) to create more financial wiggle room and allow James to take a smaller decrease.\n\nIf the Lakers don't land a star or high-level starter with their nontaxpayer midlevel exception, James will sign the max, according to ESPN. If LeBron re-signs at his max for 2024-25 (approximately $49.9 million), the Lakers will have roughly $182.3 million in committed salary. That puts them less than $8 million under the second apron ($189.5 million). James also wants to have his contract resolved before he starts practicing at the U.S. men's Olympic basketball minicamp on July 6 in Las Vegas.\n\nRegardless of what happens with James and the Lakers' exceptions, though, the Lakers are well-positioned to upgrade their roster if they so choose. The proverbial ball is in their court regarding how the rest of this offseason unfolds.\n\nLakers vice president of basketball operations and general manager Rob Pelinka tempered expectations earlier in the week -- twice -- by saying trades are harder to execute under the NBA's new collective bargaining agreement. At face value, that's true, considering the new punitive restrictions of the first and second aprons.\n\nAt the same time, the trade activity over the past week, especially near the top of the Western Conference, paints a different reality. In that time, the Oklahoma City Thunder traded for defensive ace Alex Caruso, the Minnesota Timberwolves traded for No. 8 pick Rob Dillingham, the Denver Nuggets traded up for DaRon Holmes II and salary-dumped Reggie Jackson to try to retain Kentavious Caldwell-Pope, the Dallas Mavericks salary-dumped Tim Hardaway Jr. so they can keep starter Derrick Jones Jr. (or sign Thompson) and the New Orleans Pelicans made a shrewd deal for former Lakers target Dejounte Murray.\n\nThe rest of the West is finding ways to make trades that improve their rosters or act as precursors to other moves. It's now on the Lakers to do the same.\n\nThey have the assets to make a notable trade. Russell's $18.7 million contract offers them a level of flexibility in terms of the types of players they can pursue. Add in one or both of their future first-round picks, as many as three pick swaps and the mid-sized salaries of Rui Hachimura, Jarred Vanderbilt and/or Gabe Vincent, and the Lakers can get in the conversation for just about any non-star (and even some lower-end stars). That is, again, before factoring in the potential addition of Thompson or another high-impact player for their nontaxpayer midlevel exception.\n\nAs far as trades go, the Lakers landing a third star in a deal appears unlikely, barring an unforeseen one secretly becoming available. Donovan Mitchell is reportedly likely to sign a contract extension with Cleveland, which would rule him out for the time being. Trae Young's switch from Klutch Sports to CAA also makes a trade to the Lakers less likely, as The Athletic previously reported. Murray is now in New Orleans and off the board. Perhaps Darius Garland becomes available, but he's a clear step down from the Mitchell and Young tier of stars.\n\nStill, there are good options potentially out there. Wings like Portland's Jerami Grant, former Laker Kyle Kuzma and the Nets' duo of Dorian Finney-Smith and Cam Johnson are expected to be available on the trade market, according to league sources. They aren't the biggest needle-movers, but any of those four players would enhance the Lakers' perimeter defense, frontcourt size and/or floor spacing. Grant, for his part, would check each of those boxes; he's quietly shot 40-plus percent on 3s in back-to-back seasons in Portland.\n\nThe Lakers roster, as currently constructed, is simply not good enough to come out of the Western Conference. They can win a round and maybe even two if the bracket breaks in their favor, but they have too many holes compared to the rest of the top of the West, especially on the wing. Their perimeter size, defense and overall speed and athleticism are lacking compared to their competition. James and Davis made it known recently they believe this roster needs upgrades.\n\nThe Timberwolves, Thunder, Mavericks and Pelicans all have better rosters than the ones they finished last season. Denver's standing could change if it loses Caldwell-Pope in free agency and the Clippers will likely fall off if they lose Paul George, but the larger point is the rest of the West is revamping, potentially creating even more distance between them and the Lakers. If the Lakers are as serious about competing for championships with James and Davis as they claim to be, they must bolster this supporting cast.\n\nThe most immediate complication to this effort is the roster crunch the Lakers are facing. Assuming LeBron James re-signs, they will have 14 players under contract after Russell, Christian Wood, Jaxson Hayes and Cam Reddish opted in and they drafted Knecht and Bronny James. That's before factoring in their other free agents (Max Christie, Taurean Prince and Spencer Dinwiddie) or any prospective free agents.\n\nThe Lakers tendered a qualifying offer to Christie to officially make him a restricted free agent, team sources confirmed to The Athletic. The front office would like to retain Christie and envision him as a rotation player next season, according to those sources. However, the Lakers would need to clear additional money and a roster spot to sign both Christie and another player with the nontaxpayer midlevel exception.\n\nHad Russell opted out, the Lakers would have had less optionality on the trade market. But with him opting in, James interested in taking a pay cut for the right free agent and the Lakers armed with multiple mid-sized salaries, two first-round picks and multiple pick swaps to trade, there is no excuse for Los Angeles to not dramatically improve its roster with a big move or two over the next few days.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York I'm a fan of Bronny I think he has NBA potential.\" George believes that the 19-year-old possesses the abilities required to ace in the league. He also feels that the pair will set the court on fire with their masterclass performance.\n\nLeBron and Bronny have already etched their names on the NBA books as the only father-son duo to be playing at the same time. The 39-year-old, who has expressed his desire to play alongside his offspring, can do so if he decides to stay with the franchise. {"uri": "8200942761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "02:54:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T02:54:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T02:54:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.totalprosports.com/nba/lebron-james-unfollows-rachel-nichols-over-her-blunt-remarks-about-his-son-bronny/", "title": "LeBron James Unfollows Rachel Nichols Over Her Blunt Remarks About His Son Bronny", "body": "The 2024 NBA Draft has concluded with several excellent picks from various NBA teams. Bronny James, a former guard for the USC Trojans, was chosen by the Los Angeles Lakers as the 55th overall pick in the second round of the NBA draft.\n\nThe extensive speculation surrounding Bronny has finally come to an end following his selection by the Lakers, where his father, LeBron James, is a star player. However, many NBA analyst and fans were waiting for this moment to give their reactions, with some praising the Lakers' decision and some criticizing it.\n\nRachel Nichols, an American journalist and sportscaster, recently shared her opinion on Bronny James' selection by the Lakers. She criticized the former USC Trojans guard and made bold claims about him. She believes Bronny will never be a star player like his dad, LeBron James, due to his size and playing style.\n\n\"Will he ever be a star? I don't think so. It does not seem like just his size and some of the other things about the way he plays, I don't think he's a future star player.\" Nichols said during the recent episode of the show 'Undisputed.'\n\nHowever, LeBron James didn't ignore Nichols's statement and responded in a different way. According to a recent post on the social media profile 'NBA Alert' (formerly known as Twitter), King James unfollowed Nichols after her prediction about his son Bronny.\n\n\"LeBron James (King James) is no longer following Rachel Nichols.\" The recent post of NBA Alert.\n\nNichols isn't the only one criticizing Bronny's selection by the Lakers; some NBA fans are also questioning the decision. According to people with knowledge of the decision not authorized to speak publicly, James plans to re-sign with the Lakers.\n\nThe only question is for how much?\n\nAccording to reports, James would consider taking less money should the Lakers be able to lure a high-impact free agent with the full midlevel exception -- a plan that could cost James more than $16 million next season.\n\nWhile that steep of a pay cut is viewed as unlikely, the Lakers could shed salary elsewhere to close that gap to a more palatable level. The problems, though, are multiple.\n\nOne, can the Lakers acquire an important enough addition with the midlevel exception, which begins at $13 million per season? The Lakers are willing to offer James a max three-year, $162 million contract with a full no-trade clause. Such a deal would include a no-trade clause, meaning the 39-year-old James would presumably retire as a member of the Lakers or control his next destination.\n\nJames has until 5 p.m. ET (2100 GMT) on Saturday to decide whether to opt into his player option for the 2024-25 National Basketball Association season. If James, the NBA's all-time leading scorer, opts into his contract for next season and signs an extension in August he would not be eligible for a no-trade clause.\n\nIn six seasons with the Lakers, James has expressed a desire to play alongside his son, and the duo would become the league's first father-son duo to be on the court together.\n\nBronny James' addition to the team made James' return seem more likely with the dream of playing on the same team with his son a step closer to reality. James could pick up his option for 2024-25, or he could sign a new extension for even more money. He could get a maximum three-year, $162 million deal that would give him the longest career in NBA history if he played out the contract.\n\nEither option would likely be just fine with Lakers owner 2004.\n\nBronny attracted enormous attention as a high school player at Sierra Canyon School in Los Angeles and in his senior year was joined by his younger brother Bryce, a 17-year-old who could also potentially play in the NBA one day.\n\nLast summer Bronny suffered a cardiac arrest while training with the University of Southern California (USC) basketball team and was placed in intensive care.\n\nHe was cleared to return to the team in November and went on to average 4.8 points, 2.8 rebounds and 2.1 assists per game playing guard in his lone season with the Trojans.\n\nThere was some {"uri": "8201322184", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:34:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:34:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:33:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/lakers-clearly-hope-to-lock-down-lebron-for-good/article_ebdaced0-a75b-52b6-b181-5e5ff4d8b514.html", "title": "Lakers clearly hope to lock down LeBron for good", "body": "The Los Angeles Lakers have hired JJ Redick and drafted Bronny James, pictured. next up they hope to lock down Lebron James.\n\nGREG BEACHAM\n\nAssociated Press\n\nEL SEGUNDO, Calif. -- Three days after LeBron James' podcast partner became the Los Angeles Lakers' head coach, the team drafted James' oldest son, Bronny.\n\nUnless they rename the franchise after him next, it's difficult to think of anything more the Lakers could do to make sure the top scorer in NBA history stays with them for the rest of his matchless career.\n\nWell, short of actually acquiring a third superstar for James after years of trying.\n\nAlthough James' future still won't be a sure thing until he formally decides where he'll play next season, the Lakers' addition of his 19-year-old son in the second round of the draft Thursday seems to make it extraordinarily unlikely LeBron will be anywhere but Los Angeles in the fall.\n\n\"The biggest moments in sports happen with the Lakers,\" general manager Rob Pelinka said. \"That's how we're built, and we're excited to see this story unfold.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... St. Helena's V. Sattui Winery sued by former employee alleging wage abuse Live music at Friday Nights in the Park returns to downtown Napa Supervisor Belia Ramos files court documents alleging harassment Alta Heights residents sue city of Napa for approving day care in neighborhood Battle of the Bands coming to downtown Napa Treasury Wine Estates hit with Napa lawsuit claiming labor violations Manslaughter case over cyclist couple killed in Napa moves forward Update: Forward progress stopped on fire off Jameson Canyon Road Former American Canyon school principal charged after ex-teacher's sex abuse arrest Protesters disrupt Tyler Florence visit to inaugural Napa Cookbook Fest Update: Napa motorcyclist who died in Highway 29 collision identified Napa parents: Are Napa middle schools safe? Newsom attacks 'delusional California bashers' in unorthodox speech Napa Police: Man arrested after sexual assault Napa Town & Country Fair announces musicians, opens ticket sales\n\nLeBron and Bronny -- LeBron James Jr., that is -- would be the first father and son to play in the NBA at the same time, let alone on the same team. If LeBron Sr. picks up his $51.4 million player option for next season this week, he would guarantee he'll get to take his son to work in the fall.\n\nPelinka was careful not to get ahead of himself while triumphantly discussing Bronny's potential, but the GM acknowledged that a father-son pairing in purple and gold was \"something that could be magical.\"\n\n\"We know and have to respect, of course, that LeBron has a decision about his opt-out,\" Pelinka said.\n\n\"I'm sure he and his family and his agent will deliberate what they're going to do there, and he has freedom to decide whatever is best for him and his family. But if it worked out that he was on our team next season, NBA history could be made, and NBA history should be make in a Lakers uniform.\"\n\nWith their two major moves this week, the Lakers have made it clear they're determined to stick with James as their centerpiece and leader through his record-tying 22nd NBA season this fall and beyond.\n\nLos Angeles' new coach is JJ Redick, who hosted the \"Mind the Game\" podcast with James this year. Redick is a 15-year NBA veteran who has never coached an adult basketball game, yet the Lakers quickly made the unusual choice of hiring the broadcaster after Dan Hurley turned them down -- and Pelinka didn't deny that Redick's compatibility with James was a plus.\n\nThe Lakers then used the 55th overall pick on Bronny, who put up modest statistics in his only year of college at Southern California. Bronny James is undeniably talented, but an identical player with a different name would have been less likely to be drafted.\n\nPelinka and the Lakers scouted Bronny James extensively, and he performed solidly at the pre-draft camp and again in a workout at the Lakers' training complex, which was followed by a meeting with Pelinka. Pelinka said he never even asked Bronny what he thought about the potential pressure of playing alongside his father -- something that even LeBron has said Bronny wasn't necessarily eager to do. \"We really kept the draft process to Bronny being a Laker, and what we felt like we needed to do to help him become great,\" Pelinka said. \"We didn't talk a lot about that, just because (we) wanted to respect his dad's decision as a free agent, so that wasn't really something that came up.\"\n\nThat decision feels ever more like a formality now, depending on how James decides to do it. The 20time All-Star and four-time NBA champion has spoken repeatedly over the years of his desire to play a season with his son, and now the dream is a signature away from reality.\n\nJames could pick up his option for 2024-25, or he could sign a new extension for even more money. He could get a maximum three year, $162 million deal that would give him the longest career in NBA history if he played out the contract.\n\nEither option would likely be just fine with Lakers owner Jeanie Buss, who showed a similarly passionate loyalty to Kobe Bryant when she pushed to give him a $48.5 million extension for the final two seasons of his career despite his growing injury problems.\n\nBronny likely doesn't the get Lakers closer to winning now, but their choice with the 17th overall pick just might: Dalton Knecht, the high-scoring Tennessee wing who won the SEC Player of the Year award, appears to be one of the most pro-ready players in the draft, and not just because he's already 23 years old.\n\n\"In my mind, I thought there's no way a player that skilled would be available to us (at No. 17),\" Pelinka said. Pelinka has repeatedly tried to keep fan expectations low for a major player addition to a team that lost to Denver in the first round of the postseason, instead targeting incremental improvements to the core around James and Anthony Davis -- along with a potential upgrade on the bench from Redick's innovative basketball mind.\n\n\"We've explored every upgrade we could to make our team better,\" Pelinka said. \"Trades in general have just because more difficult because of the new CBA system, and so there's less access to making those big moves than maybe there was under the old system. But it didn't keep us from trying to look at everything, and ways to put ourselves in a position to be better.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I Check out what's clicking on Foxnews.com.\n\nLeBron James has opted out of his deal with the Los Angeles Lakers, his agent, Rich Paul, told ESPN.\n\nThe decision, although expected, comes two days after the team selected his son, Bronny, with the 55th pick in the NBA Draft.\n\nIt is widely expected the NBA's all-time leading scorer will remain with the Lakers, though, and he could very well take a pay cut from the nearly $52 million he was set to make this season.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\n\"He is prioritizing a roster improvement. He's been adamant about exuding all efforts to improve the roster,\" Paul told the network.\n\nJames joined the Lakers in 2018 after a return to the Cavaliers, where he finally gave the city of Cleveland a championship. He won his fourth NBA title with the Lakers in 2020.\n\nHe just finished his 21st season and played in his record 20th All-Star Game.\n\nAt age 39, he averaged 25.7 points, 8.3 assists and 7.3 rebounds per game, all numbers comparable to his career stats of 27.1, 7.4 and 7.5. He also set a career-high by shooting 41.7% from 3-point range, while becoming the first player to score over 40,000 points in a career.\n\nAmong players who have played more than 100 games at age 35 and older, James' 27.2 points per game are the most ever by a decent margin. Second is Michael Jordan, who averaged 22.5 in 171 games after turning 35. James has played in 262 since his 35th birthday.\n\nBRYCE JAMES THROWS COLD WATER ON PROSPECT OF PLAYING IN THE NBA WITH HIS DAD, LEBRON JAMES: 'HE'S GONNA BE 42'\n\nThe Lakers' selection of Bronny made LeBron and Bronny the first father-son duo to be active players in the NBA at the same time.\n\nBefore his collegiate career began, Bronny went into cardiac arrest in July 2023 while working out at USC. It was later revealed he had a congenital heart defect. He was cleared to return, and The Associated Press recently reported he was medically cleared to play in the NBA.\n\nLeBron once said his final year in the NBA would be with his son, so some have assumed in recent years that James would retire after playing with his son for one year. But last week, Paul said the two were not a package deal.\n\nPaul said LeBron was \"off\" the \"idea\" of playing alongside his son and was more focused on Bronny's development in the league.\n\nIt seemed peculiar, though, that Bronny had invites for workouts with at least 10 teams but only accepted two from the Lakers and Phoenix Suns. However, Paul says that was all \"by design.\"\n\nScouts weren't too kind to Bronny, with one saying he was \"not an NBA prospect.\" In his lone season with the USC Trojans, he averaged less than five points per game.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nOnce he begins the 2024-25 campaign, LeBron will make history in two ways.
